Form No. 101
Sir:-

I have the honor to report on an inspection of the Hobbema Residential School, which was made a few days ago while inspecting the Agency there. At the time of my inspection the children in residence there were just getting over an epidemic of influenza, practically everyone in the school, including the sisters had been sick in bed. During my visit at the School I looked over the building, visited the classroom, and enquired into the general management of this institution. There were 146 children in residence, there are four class rooms in the school, and the work performed in the class rooms seemed to be very satisfactory, but as this school has just been recently inspected by Mr. Scoffield, of the Provincial Department of Education, I shall not deal with the class room work.

The girls attending this school get a very good training in the way of cooking, sewing, making butter etc. Practically all the clothing used in the school is made by the girls under the supervision of the sisters, and I was well impressed with this part of the work. The boys however, get very little training in the way of outside work, as there is practically no farming carried on by this institution. This is regrettable, as this Agency is situated where the Indians must make their living by farming and stock raising.
The school raises a good garden, with 220 bushels of potatoes, 30 bushels of carrots, and an abundance of turnips, cabbages, beans, peas and corn. They have 16 milk cows, 14 of which are milking, 3 calves, 1 bull and 2 horses. The calves are evidently traded off to Indians for work etc. 866 pounds of butter was made during the summer holidays, and milk, cream and butter are fed to the children, as nothing is sold off the place. They have 125 chickens and about 20,000 eggs were purchased besides. They didn't thrash any grain on the farm but they got about 25 tons of green feed. The children are well looked after at this institution. Well fed, well clothed, and in going over the stock of clothing on hand I noted that there were several changes for each child.

The school building has been described on several occasions. Two additions have been put on the original building. Floors, stairways etc., in the old part are getting badly worn and will have to be replaced. The sisters of course brought this to my attention and wanted to know if the Department would assist them to buy the material to put in new steps in the stairway, and do some repairing to the flooring, and I informed them that at the present time the department had no funds. Everything inside the school was in first class condition spotlessly clean.

Anytime I visit this institution it always comes to my mind what a terrible thing it would be if a fire was to start in this building, as it would certainly go up in flames in a very short time. However, every precaution has been taken in the way of fire escapes, and a night watchman is employed.
In conclusion I wish to point out that as far as it is possible under present conditions the school is doing splendid work, and is satisfactory in every way, with the exception of the outside work for the boys who are attending the school. Under present arrangements however, I do not expect that this can be changed, as the school has very little land and no farming equipment whatever. The school authorities are hoping however, that the Department will take steps soon to replace this institution with a new school. I pointed out to the principal that this was doubtful for a few years under present circumstances.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant

M. Christianson
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Alberta Inspectorate.

The Secretary

OTTAWA.
Ottawa, January 4, 1937.

Rev. Sir:

Mr. Inspector Christianson has forwarded his report on his recent inspection of the Ermineskin Indian Residential School. The Department is pleased to note that conditions generally at this school are satisfactory and that the work in the classrooms is progressing, also that the girls, especially, are receiving good training in the way of cooking, sewing and making garments.

The Inspector states, however, that the boys receive little training in the way of outside work, as there is practically no farming carried on at the school other than gardening operations. The Department will be pleased if you will arrange that during the spring and summer months the boys may get every opportunity to assist in the work of gardening and in the care of the stock. As much instruction as possible should be given the boys in gardening and general farm work, in order that, when they leave school, they will have a knowledge of the work.

The Inspector also states that, owing to the construction of the buildings, there is a certain danger of fire. He states that every precaution is being taken and that the services of a night watchman are employed. Please inform the Department if the night watchman is supplied with a watchman's clock and if he makes regular rounds of the building during the nights. It is hoped you will see that every precaution is taken and that no rubbish is allowed to accumulate near the furnaces.

I shall be pleased to have a full report at your convenience regarding the outside work you are able to arrange to have the boys perform, and also with respect to the precautions taken to prevent fire.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. P. Moulin, O.M.I.,

Ottawa, January 10, 1933.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 28th ultimo, requesting to be informed if the Department would provide an expenditure of approximately $200 to carry out repairs to the stairs and floors of the Ermineskin Indian Residential School during the coming summer, also to supply a sulky plow.

For your information, I may say that certain provision is being made in our Estimates for the coming fiscal year for repairs to this building, but, at the present time, I am not in a position to state whether same will be finally approved or not. I would suggest that this matter be drawn to the attention of the Department early next spring, when full particulars should be given as to the repairs required to be undertaken and the approximate cost of any material and labour required.

Regarding the supplying of a sulky plow, I may say that we have no funds for this purpose at the present time. A request for this equipment should be forwarded in due time next spring, after our Appropriation for the next fiscal year is available.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

To the Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

We have received your letter on the report of Inspector Mr. Christianson.

We know very well the danger of fire and we take as far as we can all precautions to prevent a fire; that is: 1st. to have the children proud of their school and to be very friendly with the staff.

We have Mr. George Rogier as our night watchman. He is on his 3rd. year at this work. He has been supplied from the office at Regina with a clock and we bought a supply of paper dials. Every night he makes at least four rounds through all the parts of the school building; from the basement to the top floor and outside the building. He goes especially to the furnace department where he attends to the fire, and in the kitchen.

His hours are at 10 o'clock, it is about 1/2 an hour after the retirement of the staff; then at about midnight, finishing at half past twelve. Before 2 o'clock he is on the walk, and then again at about 4 o'clock. At five, the Rev. Sisters are up and take up the watch of the building. Mr. Rogier goes outside before retiring to bed. He takes only 3 or 4 days a year to visit his family, but then he is replaced by another person.
The older boys in winter are sawing wood and piling it. They help to store the coal.

Every day 5 boys go to the stable, to milk the cows, clean the stable and spray the manure on the field. They are shown the way to feed the cows and other cattle and the horses.

In Spring time, again the oldest work in the garden, prepare the ground. We have all the vegetables and generally a very nice garden taking the admiration of our visitors. We have a few acres about 3 or 4 for potatoes and there again we have the help of the boys for all the work. They help also in our field, where we raise greenfeed or a little grain, about 40 acres in cultivation.

I would like very much to have a new school, fire proof; and a larger patch of land for more grain and more cattle. But I know it is not quite the time to ask the Indian Department for it. If we had it I think we could in a very short time have from 175 to 200 hundred pupils.

I remain, Dear Sir,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Principal

**Universal Drive with direct engine connection**

The electric motor drive is the most convenient wherever electric power is available. The current required is so small that it may be obtained from any electric light socket.

As shown in figure No. 32, this outfit comprises an electric motor (specially built for this work), a drip shelf with extension to support the motor, a pinion shaft pulley and an idler arm, spring and pulley similar to the ones used in the universal drive.

The action of the belt tightening idler pulley is the same in starting this outfit as when starting with a universal drive. It allows the motor to reach full speed in a few seconds, but the separator cannot fail until only after about 3 minutes, thus preventing excessive strain on either the motor or the separator. With this outfit the hand crank may remain on the machine and the separation carried on if the power fails.

In ordering an electric motor outfit always give the information as directed on page 16.

**ATTACHING ELECTRIC MOTOR EQUIPMENT**

To attach the electric motor outfit, remove the pinion shaft protecting cap and replace the drip shelf with the new one. Place the idler arm on the frame hub and then put on the pulley, fastening it with the set screw. Put on the motor and belt, connect the wires and the machine is then ready for operation.

**Figure No. 32**

**HOW TO FIGURE PULLEYS**

The tight and loose pulleys on the universal drive attachment are 4 inches in diameter and should run 565 revolutions per minute to give the correct speed to the separator. The driving pulley should not be less than 3 inches wide and its diameter should be determined as follows:

To determine the correct size pulley when driving from an engine or shaft direct to the universal drive, multiply the size of pulley on the universal drive (4 inches) by its speed (565) and divide it by the speed of the engine or driving shaft.

For Example:

Assuming that the engine or driving shaft runs 300 revolutions per minute, then—

\[
\frac{565 \text{ Revolutions per minute of pulley on machine}}{4 \text{ inch diameter of pulley on machine}} = \frac{1}{1.3} \text{ inch diameter of pulley required to drive separator}
\]

\[
\frac{2100}{1500} = \frac{100}{100}
\]

If it is desired to drive the universal drive from a counter-shaft which is driven from an engine, then, by multiplying the engine pulley diameter by its speed and dividing by the required speed of the counter-shaft will give the diameter of the pulley driving the counter-shaft.
For Example:

Assuming that the counter-shaft should run 300 revolutions per minute, driven by an engine having a 6 inch pulley running 300 revolutions per minute, then—

\[
\frac{300}{6} = \text{Revolutions per minute of pulley on engine}
\]

\[
\frac{1800.0}{6.0} = \text{inch diameter of pulley required to drive counter-shaft}
\]

Commercial pulley sizes are all even inches, so in case, an odd size pulley develops from formula given above, the next larger size pulley, (for first formula) and next smaller size pulley (for second formula) should be used, as it is better to drive the separator a little too fast than a little too slow.

We do not manufacture or handle commercial pulleys or hangers. These are usually obtained from the local hardware dealer.

HOW TO ORDER POWER DRIVE EQUIPMENT

The user must decide which equipment best suits his condition and in ordering, give all information possible as to kind of power, engine, speed, etc. If you are in doubt we will gladly answer any questions.

These attachments are sold as an extra and each one is packed complete with all parts necessary to make the change. No allowance is made for return of parts replaced.

INFORMATION NEEDED WHEN ORDERING MOTOR EQUIPMENT

1.—Is the current direct or alternating?
2.—If direct give voltage.
3.—If alternating, give the number of cycles, phases and voltage.
4.—If you have a Farm Light and Power outfit simply state the name of outfit.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to report on an inspection of the Hobbema Indian Residential School made during the time I was at the Agency recently. I visited all classrooms, but as the Provincial School Inspector reports on this work I shall not dwell on this phase of the matter. There were 149 children on the roll, but only 139 present at the time of my visit; 64 boys and 75 girls.

The children all looked exceptionally well and there was no sickness in the school. They are well dressed and have a good supply of clothing. I checked this up very closely and found that the boys have four changes of clothing and two pairs of shoes. They wear fleece-lined underwear in the winter and those who do outside work are supplied with woollen underwear. The girls each have six dresses, two coats — one for Sunday and one for every-day — and three pairs of shoes. Their underwear is made out of flannellette. In winter time both boys and girls wear heavy shoes and woollen stockings that are knit at the school.

I also went into the matter of the food supplied to

Doctor Harold W. McGill,

Deputy Superintendent General,

Department of Indian Affairs,

OTTAWA.
the children and came to the conclusion that they were well fed. They have a lunch at 4 o'clock when school is dismissed. The bread at the school is mostly purchased from Wetaskiwin and delivered right at the school. I do not think this is as satisfactory as if it were made at the school, but they informed me that a certain amount of baking is always done at the school as well.

BUILDING:
The building, as the Department know, is not very satisfactory and requires a lot of repairing, but I must say that the staff do everything possible to keep it in good shape. It is kept clean and tidy throughout, and the furnishings are in good condition and seem to be well cared for. The boys' dormitory needs new flooring; also the boys' dining room. Both floors are badly worn and very difficult to keep clean as in many cases they are worn right through to the rough flooring. The steps on the stairs leading down to the basement are also badly worn. I have taken the matter of repairing these floors up with the Department in a special letter.

FARMING:
The live stock at this school consists of 15 cows, 2 horses and 2 calves. Thirteen cows were milking at the time of my visit, supplying 24 gallons of milk per day, which is all given to the children.

The school did not thresh any grain but raised 45 loads of green feed, 250 bushels of potatoes and a lot of other garden truck.

TRAINING OF PUPILS OUTSIDE OF CLASSROOM:
The girls milk the cows in the summer but this is done by the boys in winter time. They
do all the ironing in the school, and the scrubbing, &c. They make their own clothing and do a lot of fancy-work. I also questioned the sisters regarding the instructions the girls received in cooking, &c., and they assured me that every girl attending the school received a good training in household science, as all of them spent so many days each month in the kitchen and were taught to make bread, cakes, pies, &c., as well as do plain cooking. They pointed out that some of the girls were better than others, and quite a number of them were good cooks. They spend an hour daily in the sewing room until they are 15; after that they generally spend two or three hours there each day until they are 17, and the Sister Superior informed me that the last year the girls were in the school she always endeavoured to give them as much time as possible in the kitchen and sewing room. The girls also help with the garden in the summer time.

The boys look after the stable and wood, &c., but the training they receive in outside work is very limited as the farming operations at this school are so small. With only 22 head of stock to look after there is not very much activity in this line. In discussing this matter with the Rev. Father Moulin, the Principal, he informed me that the Oblate Fathers intend to take over the school next summer from the Sisters, and as soon as they did the matter of outside training for the boys would receive attention. As the Department know, Father Moulin is simply in charge of the spiritual end of the work, as the Sisters are running the institution.
STAFF:

There are 14 Sisters at the school, two maids and the Rev. Father Moulin; also two men; one who acts as night-watchman and shoemaker; the other as engineer and farming instructor.

I trust this report will be of interest to you.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

PE CALGARY, ALTA., April 26th, 1935.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to report on an inspection of the Ermineskin Indian Residential School in the Hobbema Agency. At the time of my inspection there were 147 children in residence, and I must say they all looked real well and seemed healthy and happy.

CLOTHING:

I checked over the supply of clothing and found that both boys and girls had ample clothing and were better provided for than if they were living at home. All were furnished with four and five changes, and everything in that line that could be desired, is looked after.

TRAINING OF CHILDREN:

The girls at this institution all get an excellent training in domestic science, which fits them very well for the home life on the reserve after they leave school. The only improvement I might suggest is that they bake their bread at the school instead of purchasing it from a bakery as they do now. They informed me, however, that the girls are taught how to bake bread, buns, &c.

Doctor Harold W. McGill,

Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
Training, (Continued),-

The Department will recall that in practically all my reports on this school I have mentioned that the boys were getting very little training in outside work in the way of farming and looking after stock, &c. This has been changed during the last year, since the Oblate Fathers took over the management of the school. Father Moulin, the Principal, now has an assistant -- the Rev. Father Boyer -- who looks after all the outside work, and they are endeavouring to extend their farming operations. I was quite pleased to note that a repair shop has been fixed up by Father Boyer -- a make-shift shop which Father Boyer rigged up out of an old building -- but which answers the purpose very nicely, and here the boys are instructed in blacksmithing, repair-work and carpenter work. I was amazed at some of the work they had turned out with such poor equipment. Father Boyer made some requests to provide some extra equipment for the shop, and this is being submitted to the Department in a separate letter, and I trust it will receive the consideration of the Department. The training received by the boys in this shop should be valuable to them after they leave school.

LIVE STOCK & FARMING OPERATIONS:-

The School have 21 head of cattle, 4 horses (2 of which are very small), some pigs and chickens.

Their crop last year did not amount
Live Stock & Farming, (Continued),-

to very much, and their potato crop was also very poor. Father Boyer informed me that he intended to extend their gardening operations, and also farming as much as he possible could this year, and the School authorities asked for some additional assistance in the way of live stock and farm machinery, which I have taken up in a separate letter, and if this cannot be supplied this year, I hope it will be given consideration for next year's estimates, because nothing has been asked for that is not actually required. The Indians now living in the Hobbema Agency have to depend entirely on the products of their reserves for their livelihood, and I am sure the Department will realize how necessary it is for the boys to get a good training in all branches of outside work.

BUILDING:-

I do not think it is necessary for me to go into detail to any extent in this connection, as the Department are well aware that the present building is old and dilapidated, and is one of the worst fire traps that I know of. I must say that it is kept in as good a state of repair as possible, and every precaution is being taken to meet the fire hazard. The Department furnish a night-watchman and fire drill is maintained for the children; The Agent looks after this part of it. The night-watchman carries a clock and the different stations are punched every hour during the night and this is checked up every morning by the Principal and once a month by the Agent.
Building (Continued),—

The Principal asked for 6 large fire-extinguishers: There are only 3 in the building now. Whether or not this would be of any use I cannot say. As I mentioned to Father Moulin, if there was a fire the main thing would be to get the children out, because if a fire ever got started, fire extinguishers would be of little use. They might be of some use in keeping down the fire while the children were gotten out of the building. I am leaving the matter of supplying these entirely in the hands of the Department.

GENERAL:—

As the Department are aware, this has always been a fairly good school, that is as far as the educational work carried on. The children are well cared for in every way, and they are well-fed, as I checked up on the food supplies, &c. Father Moulin, the Principal, has been there for a great many years, and is a wonderful missionary amongst the Indians. He is also a man who is very fond of the children and has the respect of the Indians.

There is a staff of 14 Sisters, the Principal, his Assistance and two lay brothers.

I might bring to the attention of the Department that some of the beds are in very bad shape: They are old and have been repaired many times, and it is practically impossible to do anything with them. The rest of the equipment in the school is in very good shape and certainly properly cared for. I noticed that the furniture in the school and even in the classrooms all looked
General, (Continued),—

as if it was brand-new, as the Sisters are continually polishing and varnishing the classroom furnishings.

There is the best of feeling between the school and the agency, and therefore everything is going along fairly satisfactorily.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,

Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

Sir:

We note that the children are in good health and also that the school authorities intend, this year, to extend their gardening and farming operations. The Department has also noted your remarks regarding the prevention of fire hazard in the building. An order is being placed here for three additional fire extinguishers.

Concerning the condition of the beds in the dormitories, certain funds are available for new equipment. If you will obtain from the Principal and forward a list, stating the number of beds required, as well as their length and width, we might be prepared to supply a reasonable number. Cher Dr. McGill,

J'aime à croire que vous avez reçu mes trois lettres précédentes et que j'aurai tôt ou tard une réponse.

Permettez-moi de revenir à la charge au sujet d'un projet dont nous nous sommes plusieurs fois entretenus mais pour lequel je ne vous ai jamais fait de demande officielle par écrit : il s'agit de la construction d'une école-pensionnat moderne à Hobema, Alta., qui remplacerait l'édifice actuel insuffisant et dangereux.

Tout d'abord vous êtes parfaitement au courant de la situation puisque vous l'avez souvent déplorée. Votre prédécesseur, l'hon. Duncan C. Scott, devait y remédier à la première occasion. Il reconnaissait les services inappréciables rendus au Département par cette école qui n'avait pas coûté un sou au Dominion et qui fonctionnait à plein rendement depuis 1859. Malgré deux rénovations qui furent faites à la bâtisse primitive en 1927 et 1929, elle ne répondait plus au besoin. En 1925 il avait envoyé M. Graham, Commissaire des Affaires à l'éducation, étudier l'état des bâtisses et voir s'il convenait de recommander l'achat au Département. M. Graham avait conclu à la nécessité urgente d'une école moderne à l'épreuve du feu.

En effet déjà à cette époque l'école était trop petite. Aujourd'hui il y a une bonne quarantaine d'enfants d'âge scolaire et en bonne santé qui devraient être admis et ne le sont pas faute de place.

Malgré toutes les précautions que nous pouvons prendre et les services d'un gardien de nuit pendant 4 mois de l'année, l'école actuelle est un nid à feu : elle est toute de bois, elle a été peinturée et repeinturée, le moindre commencement d'incendie se changerait vite en conflagration. Sans doute jusqu'ici, grâce à des soins inouïs et une vigilance constante, il n'y a pas eu d'accident ; mais combien de temps encore échapperons-nous à la menace perpétuelle du feu ?

Cette école construite il y a 40 ans n'offre pas nécessairement toutes les garanties hygiéniques des constructions modernes ; les sanités y sont moins à l'abri de la contagion et des épidémies. Sans la propreté méticuleuse et la prévoyance toujours en éveil des religieuses, l'école serait facilement un danger pour la santé déjà si affaiblie de nos enfants.

Ce sont ces raisons, et bien d'autres encore qu'il serait trop long d'énumérer, qui rendent évidente la nécessité à Hobema de la construction immédiate d'une école moderne à l'épreuve du feu. Cette école devrait être de dimensions suffisantes pour héberger au moins 175 enfants en plus du personnel, si l'on veut que la population indienne catholique des réserves environnantes puisse être admise à recevoir l'éducation à laquelle elle a droit.

General Superintendent,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Dr. McGill,

I am under the impression that you have received my three previous letters and that sooner or later I shall get an answer.

Please allow me to make new efforts with regard to a project we talked about several times and for which I have never sent you officially a written request; it is about the construction of a modern boarding school at Hobbema, Alberta, to replace the present building which is inadequate and dangerous.

First, you perfectly know the situation as you have often deplored it. Your predecessor, the Honourable Duncan C. Scott, was to remedy to it at the first opportunity. He was aware of the inestimable services rendered to the Department by this school which had cost nothing to the Dominion and which was operating at full capacity since 1896. In spite of two additions made to the first school in 1922 and in 1929, it did not satisfy the need; in 1925, Mr. Scott asked Mr. Graham, Indian Commissioner at Regina, to investigate the state of the buildings, and to see if he could recommend its purchase to the Department. Mr. Graham had come to the conclusion that a modern fireproof school was an urgent necessity.

In fact at that time the school was too small. To-day about forty school aged children in good health are denied
admittance for want of place.

In spite of all precautions we are taking and the services of a night watchman during seven months of the year, the present school is a fire trap; it is a wooden structure, painted and repainted several times, the least beginning of fire would soon become a conflagration. Undoubtedly up to the present, owing to incessant cares and continuous vigilance, there was not accident; but how long will we still be preserved from the perpetual fire menace?

This school, built some forty years ago, does not necessarily offer all the hygiene guarantees of modern structures; health is less protected from contagion and epidemic diseases. Without the scrupulous cleanliness and the cautious measures of the nuns, the school would easily be a menace to the health, already impaired of our children.

For these reasons, and many others which would be too long to enumerate in this letter, it is evidently urgent to build immediately a modern fireproof school at Hobson. This school should be sufficiently large to accommodate at least 175 children besides the staff, if we want the Catholic Indians of the surrounding reserves to receive the education to which they are entitled to.

Furthermore, the new school built on the present school site, a short distance from the Canadian Pacific Railway, on the national highway from Edmonton to Calgary, and to the international boundary, would be to the Canadian population, as well as to the numerous tourists, a magnificent evidence of the work done by the Department of Indian Affairs for the Indian children, whose guardian it is on behalf of the Government of Canada.

Finally such a construction in this time of crisis and unemployment would provide a large number of men with work and bread and at a considerable saving to the public treasury on account of the comparatively low cost of manual labour.

May I add that the nine hundred Indian families who patronise this school unanimously demand for their children a modern structure where health would progress in more hygienic conditions and where lives would be better protected from fire menace.

Hoping that you will do your utmost to hasten the realiza-
tion of our wishes and to lessen the anxieties of our heavy responsibilities on account of the circumstances in which our work is done at Redfern, I beg to remain

Yours very truly,

(Signed) U. Langdon, C.M.

May 12, 1936.

Dear Father Langlois:

I have your letter of the 3rd instant, stressing the need of a new building, to provide accommodation for 175 children and staff, to replace the present old Ermineaskin Indian Residential School building.

I concur in the opinion expressed by you, regarding the condition of the present building, viz.: that it constitutes a fire hazard, is unsanitary and does not provide facilities for pupils and staff.

When our Estimates for Indian Education for the current fiscal year were in course of preparation, definite instructions were received to cancel all appropriations for new school buildings. There are no funds available, in either the Appropriation for Indian Education or the Public Works Construction programme, to provide the amount that would be required in the erection of a new and modern fire-proof building. The needs at this point will not be lost sight of, but I am unable, at present, to give any promise when funds will be provided to erect a new school. Mr. Christianson, in a report on his inspection of the present school on the 17th ultimo, states that the building and equipment is kept in good condition by the Reverend Sisters and that he considers, under the circumstances, the school is doing very good work.

School

At the first treaty we were promised schools for our children by the Representatives of the Queen.

I am glad to say that one school was given to us on our Reserve, now known by the name of Erminiskin's Residential School. For this I am very grateful and offer my most sincere thanks to those who granted it and are still supporting it.

But I have to say:

It is a very old building, an inadequate old building. We heard that in other Reserves, such were burnt, and children were lost in the fire. We now wish to have a school like those we have seen on Blood and Blackfoot Reserves or at St. Paul. The Reverend Priest [illegible] Principal, has, for the last ten years told us it was coming soon. But the years are long....

Inadequate: the actual capacity of the school is not sufficient. There could be more children at school and we do not like to see them go far away from us.

In my name and in the name of all the Hobbema Catholic Indians, I ask to hasten the building of a new and modern school on our Reserve, at Hobbema.

INSPECTOR'S OFFICE
PB CALGARY, ALTA., June 9th, 1936.

Sir:

I beg to attach hereto 2 resolutions sent to this office by Col. R. H. Palmer, Indian Agent, Hobbema, on behalf of Pany Ermineeskin, chief of that band.

The first resolution deals with pensions, and that is a matter that is very frequently brought to my attention at all agencies; The Indians are fully aware of what is taking place in White settlements, that all White people over the age of 70 who are indigent are placed on a pension of $20.00 per month, whereas the Indians are only placed on the ration list and very often when they are much older than 70. The ordinary ration is probably worth about $2.00 per month, and where special rations are given these come to a little more. Personally I have always thought the Indians had a fairly good argument, although I have not admitted this to them, and I feel that in a great many cases the old people are not given the consideration they should get and I hope that sometime in the near future the Government of Canada will go into this matter and see what can be done. I might say this is one of the matters that Pany Ermineeskin wanted to take up with the Department at Ottawa personally when he was trying to get down there last winter, and several other Chiefs also had this in mind when they wanted to go to Ottawa; in fact this was to be one of their main requests.

The second resolution deals with the matter of a new school at Hobbema: The Department are fully aware that the present Ermineeskin School is a bad fire hazard as the Chief states; also it is a very old building, and for a great many years now representations have been made to the Government that a new building is required at this Agency. I can only add that the policy of the Government is to continue boarding schools for the Indians, this is one place where a new school is certainly required. I trust these matters will receive the full consideration of the Department, and that I be advised in due course.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,

Cher Dr. McMillan,

J'arrive d'un voyage d'inspection à l'Ecole Indienne Crowfoot à Edmonton, Alta. Vous me permettrez à la suite de ce voyage et des constatations pénibles que j'y ai faites - constatations dont je vous ai à plusieurs reprises entretenus ainsi que votre honorable prédécesseur - d'insister encore une fois sur la pressante nécessité de la construction d'un local plus moderne, plus commode, plus hygiénique et plus sûr pour la vie des enfants confiés par le Canada à la sollicitude de votre Département.

Le personnel que j'y ai vu à l'Ecole est admirable de dévouement, de vigilance, de savoir-faire et d'intérêt dans sa tâche de relèvement de la nation indienne jusqu'à la hauteur de notre civilisation. Il travaille cependant dans des conditions plutôt adveres, comme vous ne l'ignorez pas.

Il y a bien des années qu'une école neuve a été promise pour Edmonton, mais j'ai entendu cette promesse sur les lèvres de M. le Commissaire Graham de Regina, dès 1938; l'honorable Macdonald ne l'a renouvelée à moi-même plus d'une fois, et depuis janvier 1939 on n'a cessé de me raider que cette école était la première sur la liste.

Je suis dans le meilleur sens de mon provincialat et le véritable oblige à admettre que je n'ai jusqu'à rien obtenu qui vaille pour les Indiens sous ma juridiction. J'avais cependant entendu l'espoir de servir avant la fin de mon terme, de faire commencer les travaux d'agrandissement de Chilcotin et de construction d'écoles dont l'urgence s'attache aux yeux de tout le monde. Il se peut que je n'insiste pas assez, mais je ne vous force pas suffisamment le main-pieds. J'avoue qu'il me réjouit d'employer certains procédés et de faire jouer certaines influences. Je ne peux pas préférer respecter la liberté d'action des officiers supérieurs du Département et leur faire confiance. D'autres ont été moins réservés que moi et s'en sont mieux trouvés.

Loin de moi la pensée d'en rejeter le blâme sur vous et sur vos aides; les circonstances y sont sans doute pour beaucoup. Toutefois il me semble que notre tour d'être aidés et secourus devrait être ou tard venir.

Veuillez croire à mes meilleurs sentiments,

[Signature]

Mr. Ben it,

Edmonton, Alta., Feb. 16, 1937.

Dear Mr. McGill,

I have just returned from an inspection trip to the Ermineskin Indian school at Hobbema, Alta. every one will admit. Dear Sir,

With further reference to our conversation of the 14th instant, I would ask you to take into consideration and to present to the Honourable Minister the request I made to you the other day, viz.: to build immediately a residence for the Principal and the teachers of the Erminskin Indian boarding-school at Hobbema, Alta.

The house they now occupy was built of logs about fifty years ago. At different times it was improved and that has made it more or less habitable until this day. We hoped it would stand up until a modern school could be built and which would provide living quarters for the Principal and his staff. But the Government finances compel the Department which you have the honour of serving, to defer until a later date a building proposition which has been promised us and which is so needed, so we are now obliged to ask the Honourable Mr. Grégar not to delay much longer at least the building of a residence for the Principal of Erminskin school and his staff.

Their dwelling quarters are now falling to pieces. The centre part has no solid foundation and the logs used for the walls are rotten. This house has no modern convenience whatever; no running water, sewer, toilet or furnace; six stoves, heated all winter long, does not prevent water from freezing in the basins during the night. Such lack of comfort and unhygienic conditions are not only hard on the school staff, but they have affected their health, to such an extent that I cannot ask them to spend another winter in a house which is coming apart.
Mr. Christianson, General Inspector of Indian Agencies and Mr. Schmidt, Inspector for Alberta, have found out for themselves all the inconveniences one can experience during the hard winter months in a house such as that and they can confirm my statements.

To repair this house in order to put it into shape again, would mean an expenditure of many hundred dollars, almost the price of a new one, and it would soon be in the same state again. So that it seems that money spent on repairs would be of no avail.

There remains the alternative of building a new home for the Principal and his staff; this is what has seemed to be the best solution and that is why I solicit your help as well as I plead your Honourable Minister to be kind enough to grant me this favour. A house could easily be built to fit in with the others which will subsequently be the future residential school of Erminskin. For this reason, Inspector Schmidt may have to be asked to choose a site to correspond with the general plan of the future buildings.

I am told that the financial standing of the Department of Indian Affairs is the great obstacle in the way of this project which would entail an expenditure of from $5,000 to $10,000. We are anxious to prove to you that we understand your difficulties and to convince you of our willingness to come to a favourable solution; I would suggest the following arrangement: The Oblate Fathers would borrow the necessary amount and build this residence under the understanding that the Department of Indian Affairs would reimburse this loan as well as the interest thereon to the Oblate Fathers, either by paying the whole amount next year, or by yearly instalments, according to the agreement.

You can be assured that I bring this matter to your knowledge only because it is practically impossible for me to ask my missionaries to live much longer in this old house which has not cost a cent to the Department and which we have been happy to put at the disposal of the teachers of the Erminskin school at Hobbema for a period of 50 years.
I sincerely hope that the Honourable Mr. Grégar, the worthy Minister of Mines and Resources, will give a favourable hearing to my pressing request and that he will make haste to come to the rescue of the Oblate missionaries always willing to cooperate fully with the Department of Indian Affairs in helping the progress of civilization amidst the Indian population of Canada.

Please accept, dear Mr. Gamsell, my best regard.

(Signed) U. Langlois, O.M.I.,

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER -

Re: Ermineskin Residential School.

I am returning herewith letter, dated Ottawa, June 18, 1937, received by you from Reverend U. Langlois, O.M.I.

I may state that the Ermineskin Residential School is situated on the Ermineskin reserve, approximately 45 miles south of the city of Edmonton, close to the Calgary-Edmonton highway. This school building is one of the oldest residential schools in the country. It is not owned by the government but was built approximately 50 years ago, by the Oblate Order. It has not been purchased by the government. It has, at the present time, a pupilage of 140 and receives from the Department per capita grant of $170. The last report indicates that there are at the school 153 pupils. The staff consists of the principal - Reverend Father Loulin; the Assistant principal - Reverend Father J. B. Boyer; two brothers; one Engineer; and 16 sisters.

The building to which Rev. Father Langlois refers is a separate building, detached from the educational unit, and has been used as a residence for the principal and the brothers associated with him on the staff. The sisters are provided with accommodation in the main building.

The departmental records indicate that, for a number of years prior to 1930, it was the policy of the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs to either build or purchase from the church authorities at least one residential school.
school each year. This policy was abandoned, in the interest of economy. If the policy had been continued, however, the Brineskin School would have been purchased with the object of building a new residential school on the Brineskin reserve during the year 1931. The claims of this school were very carefully reviewed in 1930 and an inspection of the buildings made, with the object of instituting a building programme the next year.

The pupils in attendance at this school come from the following reserves:

**Hobbema Agency**

| Reserve          | Boys | Girls |
|------------------|------|-------|
| Brineskin Reserve| 27   | 33    |
| Amson            | 33   | 34    |
| Louis Bulla      | 8    | 11    |
| Pontana          | 3    | 2     |

**Edmonton Agency**

| Reserve          | Boys | Girls |
|------------------|------|-------|
| Enoch Reserve    | --   | 2     |

Total - 71 boys 82 girls

These figures suggest that a residential school is necessary at this reserve. In view of the distances and other factors, the ordinary day school or even an improved day school could scarcely be operated successfully in this district. Father Langlois intimates that the Oblate Fathers are willing to borrow the amount of money necessary (approximately $10,000) to build a residence for the Principal and Brothers, on the understanding that he would be reimbursed next year or over a period of years by instalments. He was, no doubt, prompted to make this offer owing to the uninhabitable character of the present residence, which, according to our reports, is in a very unsanitary and dilapidated condition. It should be pointed out, also, that the school itself, owing to its age, has become a real fire hazard.

It should be pointed out, however, that the

- Government
Government, in its construction of residential schools operated under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church, has never in any case made provision for a principal's residence by the erection of a separate building. In these schools, without exception, an office and living quarters are provided for the principal and the members of the staff in the main building. Such a unit lends itself to more economical operation. It has been considered wise to have the principal in the main building and on hand in case of an emergency. It is important that this fact be kept in mind, in view of the request before us for consideration.

In view of all the circumstances, I submit for consideration the following recommendations:

1. That a residential school be built on the Ermineskin reserve at the earliest possible date and that an item to cover the cost be included in next year's estimates.

2. That this residential school consist of one unit, equipped for vocational instruction and academic courses, with living accommodation for the principal and all the members of the staff, and that the building be of fireproof construction.

This may appear to be a waste of money, but I can think of no alternative.

The departmental records indicate that, for a number of years prior to 1930, it was the policy of the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs to either build or purchase from the church authorities at least one residential school.
school each year. This policy was abandoned, in the interests of economy. If the policy had been continued, however, the Ermineskin School would have been purchased with the object of building a new residential school on the Ermineskin reserve during the year 1931. The claims of this school were very carefully reviewed in 1930 and an inspection of the buildings made, with the object of instituting a building programme the next year.

The pupils in attendance at this school come from the following reserves:

**Hobbema Agency**

| Reserve          | Boys | Girls |
|------------------|------|-------|
| Ermineskin Reserve | 27   | 33    |
| Samson           | 33   | 34    |
| Louis Bulls      | 8    | 11    |
| Montana          | 3    | 2     |

**Edmonton Agency**

| Reserve          | Boys | Girls |
|------------------|------|-------|
| Enoch Reserve    | 2    |       |

Total - 71 boys 82 girls

These figures suggest that a residential school is necessary at this reserve. In view of the distances and other factors, the ordinary day school or even an improved day school could scarcely be operated successfully in this district. Father Langleis intimates that the Oblate Fathers are willing to borrow the amount of money they may (approximately $10,000) to build a residence for the Principal and Brothers, on the understanding that he would be reimbursed next year or over a period of years by instalments. He was, no doubt, prompted to make this offer owing to the uninhabitable character of the present residence, which, according to our reports, is in a very unsanitary and dilapidated condition. It should be pointed out, also, that the school itself, owing to its age, has become a real fire hazard.

It should be pointed out, however, that the

- Government
Government, in its construction of residential schools operated under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church, has never in any case made provision for a Principal's residence by the erection of a separate building. In these schools, without exception, an office and living quarters are provided for the Principal and the members of the staff in the main building. Such a unit lends itself to more economical operation. It has been considered wise to have the Principal in the main building and on hand in case of an emergency. It is important that this fact be kept in mind, in view of the request before us for consideration.

In view of all the circumstances, I submit for consideration the following recommendations:

1. That a residential school be built on the Ermineaskin reserve at the earliest possible date and that an item to cover the cost be included in next year's Estimates.

2. That this residential school consist of one unit, equipped for vocational instruction and academic courses, with living accommodation for the Principal and all the members of the staff, and that the building be of fireproof construction.

3. That the small appropriation of $550.00, included in this year's Estimates be used in an attempt to render the present Principal's residence as comfortable as it is possible to make it until the new building is constructed. This may appear to be a waste of money, but I can think of no alternative.

The Minister hesitates to commit the Government to financial obligations that extend into the future. It is felt that the practice of committing the Government to financial obligations without reference to Parliament is constitutionally unsound and exceedingly difficult to justify, even in an emergency. The outside dimensions of the building are 40'5" by 136' and the building may be divided into three sections. On the south end is the original building with no basement, this being added to by the major portion of the building with full basement. These two sections were built upward of fifty years ago. The north portion of classrooms with sleeping quarters above was built some twenty years ago; the basement being extended at that time to take in this newest addition.

**BASEMENT**

This was inspected from south to north.

**Sleeping Quarter**, 10' x 14'

This room is occupied by one sister. The ceiling is 5'11" in height and is in very poor condition. The floor is of uncovered cement and is very damp. No windows or ventilation of any kind. Wall is of uncovered cement.

**Sleeping Quarter & Storeroom**, 10' x 16'

This room is occupied by one sister and is also used as a storeroom for clothing. The ceiling is 5'11" and is supported by 2" x 10" joists in fair condition. Floor is cement and very damp. Walls are of uncovered cement with one small window for light and ventilation.

**Children's Sleeping Quarter**, 14' x 58' (See Photo No.1)

This room is occupied by thirteen children ranging in age from 7 to 10 years of age. The room is divided roughly into two parts: the west portion of 14' x 16' being in the poorest shape and described as follows. Seven feet in height from floor to stringers with one uncovered cement wall and the other two of rough boards. The floor above is supported by 7 - 8" round logs running lengthwise of the room, at the one end they are nailed into a 12" hewn timber plate which rests on top of the concrete outside wall. The stringers are supported here and there by 3" poplar posts and 2" x 6", shimmied up with common box boards.

The 12" x 12" plate and the seven (7) stringers are almost wholly destroyed by dry rot and crumble easily to the touch, thus rendering the room unsafe for occupancy. This section has no windows or ventilation and with the odor of dry rot being prominent it is unhealthy.

The east portion of this room is 14' x 21'. The joists are 7' above the floor with no ceiling. The 7 - 2" x 10" joists which support this section are imbedded in the concrete wall on the one end, and rest on 2 - 6" x 7" beams running crosswise, one in the middle and one on the opposite end. Beams are supported by 3 - 2" x 6" planks nailed together and by 2 - 8" round posts. Two walls are of concrete while the other is rough boards. Two sets of steam pipes cross this room 5' from the floor.
Stateroom. 8' x 10'
This room is dark and damp, with one small window set at ground level. The ceiling of 1" boards is plased and patched, while 3" poplar posts are used to support the joists above.

Bakery.
One beam runs lengthwise of the ceiling and this has sagged some 2" in the middle. The ceiling is of V joint which is badly buckled and which springs under pressure. The chimney in the corner is brick covered with cement, and a large area of brick is exposed, as the cement is falling away.

Dining & Recreation Hall. 30' x 30'
This room has an 8' ceiling and two beams run across it as support. These beams have sagged badly and the V joint ceiling gives easily when pressed. Seven 6" x 6" badly checked, rough sawn posts support the beams.

Pantry. 14' x 20'
A piece of the V joint ceiling was taken out in this room, and this exposed round log beams almost wholly destroyed by dry rot, they crumbling to the touch. This room has two small windows.

Recreation & Dining Hall. (See Photo No.2)
This basement room is in the portion built some twenty years ago. Fifteen, 2" x 10", fairly sound, exposed joists, support the floor above. The walls of this room are uncovered cement. The hot water tank to service the whole building is located in the corner of this room; this being heated by means of a jacket heater which is located in the boiler room. Narrow stairs in fair condition lead from the corner of this room to the classroom above.

Boiler Room.
The boiler appears to be in fair condition, and has been recently inspected and pronounced serviceable.

THIRD FLOOR

This floor was inspected from north to south.

Girls Dormitory. 26 beds.
This is the newest portion of the building. The floor has dropped toward the centre and has sunk 1" on the north end and is approximately 5" lower in the centre of the room than along the walls. As in the boys dormitory the quarters are cramped. The roof leaks on the North end.

Girls Dormitory. 41 beds.
This large room is in the oldest portion of the building. Lengthwise through the centre of the room the floor is roughly 4" lower than along the outside walls. This room is overcrowded.

Girls Dormitory. 22 beds. (See Photo No.6)
This room is also in the oldest portion of the building. The floor slopes toward the middle, it being some 4" lower than the outside. This room is also crowded.

For the above ninety-one (91) girls there are two lavatories available.
There is a sheet metal bathtub at the south end of the centre dormitory which is almost destroyed by rust, and although it is not in use, it should be taken out as soon as possible, and replaced with a new one.

FOURTH FLOOR

This floor is in the roof peak and is unfinished, being used for storage only. The stairs leading to this floor slope badly toward the centre of the building and should be trued up. The floor is of common boards and it sags badly through the centre.

The chimney on the North end is cement and appears to be in good condition.

The ventilation pipe runs through the centre of the room, and this pipe was separated some 2" at one joint, rendering it useless. It was told that it was impossible to keep the joints of this pipe together as the sway of the building jars the joints, during a wind. This pipe should be fixed permanently as soon as possible.

WATER SYSTEM

A single action pump driven by an electric motor is used; the water being pumped through a 1" pipe from a well. The motor is located in an annex to the west of the main building (See photo No.5). The water is pumped into a galvanized lined wooden tank located on the fourth floor of the main building, and from there gravity feeds it through the house system.

The capacity of the tank is approximately 800 gallons and the filling of it is a slow process.

By test, a 3/4" pipe in the kitchen delivered 2.4 gallons per minute.

Two wells are in use, one being used with the motor and the other by a hand pump in the kitchen. This latter is hard water.

Apparently the water has not been tested for some time and this should be done as soon as possible.

FIRE PROTECTION

There are four 50-foot lengths of 1 1/2" hose with racks near the west end of the building, one on each floor.

The fire escapes are the old fashioned pole type, with one set of steps on the west side.

The second floor has three outlets: a pole escape in the centre on the north end, a drop ladder on the west side on the north end, and a pole escape on the west side on the south end.

The third floor has three escapes: a pole from the centre on the north end, steps from the centre on the west side and a pole escape on the west side on the south end.
VERANDA.

The veranda is on the front of the building and runs for almost the full length of the building on the second floor being entered from the inside only. This veranda has been constructed in inferior condition and not safe for any heavy loading. At the present time, it is not in use and I suggested to Father Pratt, the principal of the school, that it should be closed off and not used until it has been repaired.

ANNEX

The annex is west of the main building and the electric water pump and laundry is located on the ground floor. The laundry equipment is fairly modern, although the boiler shows signs of leaking and should be checked over.

The second floor was intended for the infirmary and nurses' quarters, but is not being used as such. The reason given is that it cannot be heated efficiently in the winter time. At the present time, it is being used as a drying and ironing room.

At the time of inspection, the building housed the following:

155 Boys and girls ranging in age from 7 to 16 years.
17 Sisters of the Catholic Church.
1 Brother acting as fireman and janitor.

The above children are all Cree Indian and the principal informed me that there are some 50 more applications on file for entrance to the school but not sufficient accommodation is available.

Re: Eymineskin Residential School, Hobbema, Alberta.

I inspected the above school on June 2nd, accompanied by Father J.E. Pratt, principal of the school, C.D. Schmidt, Inspector of Indian Affairs Branch, Calgary, and the Mother Superior of the school.

The attached memorandum, pages 1 to 4 inclusive, describes quite accurately the condition of the various rooms as to sag in floors and condition of floor beams and supports in the basement.

This in general is the condition of the school:

(1) The floor beams and supporting columns, holding up the floor over the basement, weakened with age and rot, have let the centre of the building sag. This sag is of course transmitted to, and shows in the floors of the rooms above. A new layout of joists, beams, columns and plates will be required over all the first floor above basement, except the northern part of building which was erected some twenty years ago.

(2) The floor joist construction as originally built, is much too light and while much of the upper floors is still sound and serviceable, there is an unavoidable deflection in the floor joists. For example, the main floor is carried on 2" x 6" joists 24" centers on an 18 foot span. For a little floor live load of say 50 pounds per square foot the span should not be over ten (10) feet for 2" x 6" joists on 24" centers. Or, for an 18 foot span 2" x 6" joists on 18" centers should have been used.

Similarly, the floors under some of the dormitories are carried by 2" x 6" joists on 24" centers for a 16 foot span. For a 40 pound live load of 40 pounds, on a 16 ft. span, 2" x 6" floor joists should not have been used, but 2 x 10 joists 12" centers. Carrying a 40 pound live load on 2 x 8 joists 24" centers, and 16 foot span, reduces the factor of safety to about three instead of six and gives a theoretical deflection of approximately 2 1/4 inches. As a matter of fact the actual live floor load in one of these dormitories would average about as follows:

Bed, bedding and one person, 300 lbs., distributed over an area of approximately 25 sq. ft. = 12 pounds per sq. ft.
Live load plus 13 pounds dead load = 25 pounds total load which would give a deflection of around 1 1/2 inches and a safety factor of approximately 5. The floor construction although too light, will carry the light dormitory floor load, but there is of necessity the extra deflection in the floor joists. Where possible and necessary these long spans are to be halved and supported by an extra beam and posts.

(Signed)...........
(3) Along the center line of the building, the floor joists rest on a central beam. This beam is supported either by partitions or by wooden posts or columns. In places these supporting posts are too far apart and permit a deflection in the beam. Additional posts are to be added and the spacing of the posts is to be changed as required.

(4) The floors of the building should be jacked up into shape as much as possible after the new beams, joists and posts have been placed in the basement.

(5) Floors, doors, windows, and V joint wall and ceiling covering. While this material is old and worn and in places the V joint has warped away from the joists, it is considered that a 10 or 20% replacement will be sufficient and all that the general condition of the building warrants.

(6) The building should be painted outside and some slight repairs made to the verandahs and fire escape stairways.

(7) At present the water supply and distribution system is totally inadequate. There is not sufficient for domestic purposes and in case of a fire the protection from the fire hose, which is located on the north end of the building, would be totally inadequate. I would recommend, therefore, the drilling of a new well and the installation of an electric pump, pressure tanks and additional piping, all as described in the Bill of Material attached hereto.

In my opinion the building as a whole, although of too light construction and old, is still serviceable enough to warrant the repairs herein described. Care will have to be exercised always to not overload the dormitory and attic floors.

I give below a summary of the costs estimated -

Extract from letter dated July 6, 1938, received from Dr. J. J. WALL.

It is with respect to the fire hazard at night in four of our schools. They are Sandy Bay, Man., Round Lake and Cowessess of Broadview, Sask., and lastly and especially Hobbema, Alta. In any of these institutions, should I sleep there, I always have the flash-light, overcoat, socks and gloves available and prepared for a sudden dive into the winter night. This fear in these four places certainly has not become an obsession but it has started to bother my conscience.

I know how foolish it would be in these hard times to imagine that funds are available for proper reconstruction. But is it not possible to get proper escape apparatus installed. Every second for evacuation time must be conserved. I am not frightened so much of the flames at night but I am fearful of the superheated gases developing and flooding the halls. One partial lung-full of this and a person is out. All the fire fighting equipment possible will not avail such a case. That was my experience years ago at the Royal Victoria in Montreal when we had that terrible movie fire which took so many children. It was not the flames, as I recollect, none were even scorched.

My belief is that this problem can be solved in preparing proper escapes. Iced poles of iron, narrow snow or ice filled metal stairs on the outside possibly open to a wall of flames from some window it passes will only add to the panic at night. Poor lighting over these meager affairs will not assist.

The panic in the children when a real fire does break will be stupendous. The stoical Indian in such case is a figment on the part of certain popular authors.

Don't be sore at me, Phil., as I am prepared to lay a two to one bet up to $100 bucks that in case of such an eventuality in any of the four, happening in winter between ten at night and four in the morning, the mortality will exceed...
thirty per cent.

The ideal thing would be an inspection of each by an officer, like the Chief of the Montreal brigade, who has had plenty of experience dealing with such institutional hazards. His first consideration would be to figure the route the fire and gases would take so that adequate methods and routes of escape can be instituted. Steel fire doors would undoubtedly be installed on each floor above the first. Steel tower-like escapes as on the Kent Street School at Ottawa would replace at strategic points the old precarious poles and narrow stairs. Lists of pupils to utilize each escape would be posted at all times and each child's name checked from list as it passes by a responsible guardian. Many of the children otherwise, in the event of a genuine alarm will, if not watched, take refuge in a clothes closet or under its bed.

Night watchman was a step in the right direction but much can happen in the winter when he is punching in the outbuildings and barn and the time he returns to the school.

Much as I hate to bring your attention to this whole question in these four places, please understand it is not done so with any sense of butting in. It is for these poor kiddies sake, many of whom one becomes attached in his duties. In case also, should any catastrophe arise, we all shall be charged properly at any investigation especially at the hands of politically conscious lawyers who cynically will give little credit to those who really and truly have the fullest interests of these tots at heart.

To Mr. H.W. McGill;

Dear Sir,

I am writing to you on behalf of Rev. Father Routhier, our new Provincial, who replaced Father Langlois. Having been Provincial Procurator for the past two years, I have been in touch with our Indian Schools and more than ever in condition to know their needs, for the present at least.

The Department, I understand, has voted a certain sum for repairs and another sum for additions to the Eriniskin School at Hobbema. We thought that if you would kindly let us have the sums voted, we would take upon ourselves to make the repairs and additions with more advantages than by giving a Government contract. We have a few Lay Brothers who are competent carpenters and we would employ them for the work. No doubt; we would like the work to be supervised by a man appointed by the Department.

We have another proposal to make to you. The School at Brocket needs to be enlarged. Well we have at McLeod a school that has been abandoned by the Sep. S.D. This is a brick building 65x65 feet. We had a contractor from Lethbridge to look at the building. This contractor estimated that, after allowing for breakage, 100,000 bricks could be salvaged. He estimated the cut stone at 80 cubic feet. The windows, sashes, doors, and lumber were in good condition. This building belongs to the Oblate Fathers and we offer it free to the Department to be used for the addition at Brocket. You would have only the cost of salvaging the material and hauling them at Brocket which is only twenty two miles from McLeod.

Hoping these proposals will be taken into consideration by your Department.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Sir:

I beg to report that when at the Hobbema Agency on the 21st instant, I called at the Ermineskin Residential School, where certain repairs are being done to the main building, a new well is being sunk, and a pressure tank installed.

Work on the repairs is advancing nicely; this, together with the painting of the exterior, will make a big improvement to the main building. This, however, does not alter the fact that the building is too small, there being no infirmary; also, a number of the pupils and some of the staff have to sleep in the basement, which is not a proper or suitable place; also, as the Department are aware, there are a large number of R.C. children of school age in this Agency, who are not attending school, there being no room for them.

At the time of my visit, drilling of the new well had reached a depth of 345 feet; they were then going through a layer of shale. I have this day phoned Agent Lewis, making inquiries, and he informs me that water was found at 400 feet, and that the level of this comes up to 200 feet. A test shows the well to supply four (4) gallons per second. The pressure tank, when filled, will operate two ordinary fire hose for a period of fifteen minutes. I have asked Agent Lewis to obtain a log of the well; also to have the water analysed and both records filed at his office and copies sent here.

When on the reserve, threshing was proceeding nicely. Agent Lewis informed me today that this will be completed on Monday, the 31st instant.

Your obedient servant,

Calgary, October 29th, 1936.

Sir:

I beg to report that when at the Hobbema Agency on the 21st instant, I called at the Ermineskin Residential School, where certain repairs are being done to the main building, a new well is being sunk, and a pressure tank installed.

Work on the repairs is advancing nicely: This, together with the painting of the exterior, will make a big improvement to the main building. This, however, does not alter the fact that the building is too small, there being no infirmary; also, a number of the pupils and some of the staff have to sleep in the basement, which is not a proper or suitable place; also, as the Department are aware, there are a large number of R.C. children of school age in this Agency, who are not attending school, there being no room for them.

At the time of my visit, drilling of the new well had reached a depth of 345 feet! They were then going through a layer of shale. I have this day phoned Agent Lewis, making enquiries, and he informs me that water was found at 400 feet, and that the level of this comes up to 200 feet. A test shows the well to supply four (4) gallons per second. The pressure tank, when filled, will operate two ordinary fire hose for a period of fifteen minutes. I have asked Agent Lewis to obtain a log of the well; also to have the water analysed and both records filed at his office and copies sent here.

When on the reserve, threshing was proceeding nicely. Agent Lewis informed me today that this will be completed on Monday, the 31st instant.

Your obedient servant,

C. Fant Schmidt,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

Sir:

In reply to your 112-1-5 of the 26th Oct. 1938, I beg to inform you that I interviewed the Acting Principal of the Ermineskin School regarding the expenditure of the balance of approximately $2400.00 provided in the current year's estimates for repairs, etc.

The Rev. Father Pratt wishes to erect a 2 story building 40' x 60', erected approximately 40 feet north of the main building. The basement to be used as a boys' recreation room, the ground floor to contain 4 class rooms and the first floor to contain a dormitory and an infirmary. The attic to be unfinished.

Father Pratt wishes to arrange for his own labour and to get his lumber from B.C. in car load lots and to have an engineer from the Surveys and Engineering Branch to supervise the work. He is hopeful that his Superior will authorize a further expenditure to complete the building.

I hope that something can be done to enlarge this building, as at present there are 2 Sisters and about 20 small children sleeping in the basement, which is not healthy; there are also 34 children sick in bed in the dormitories. 31 have mumps, 2 with chicken-pox and 1 with pneumonia. These children should be in an infirmary. There are also about 60 children who should be in school, but cannot be taken in as there is not room for them.

Your obedient servant,

Alfred G.B. Lewis,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 2nd instant with reference to the new building that the Principal of the Ermineskin Residential School wishes to erect.

From the information given in your letter I am inclined to feel that the proposed new building would cost in the vicinity of $20,000.00. As you are aware only $5,400.00 is available and I am unable to hold out any promise that additional funds will be available in the appropriation for the next fiscal year to complete the building proposed by the Reverend Principal nor to provide per capita grant over and above the number which is allowed at present.

Unless the Reverend Principal is definitely assured that his superior will provide the funds without making any further demand on this Branch I believe he would be well advised to consider the matter further before taking any definite steps. This Branch would prefer a building with class rooms on the ground floor and the basement used for vocational training. Buildings such as this would cost considerably less than the one suggested by the Reverend Principal and at the same time the removal of the class rooms to such a building would permit of the present class rooms being used for dormitory accommodation.

You should, therefore, discuss the matter again with the Reverend Principal and let me have your views.

A.G.B. Lewis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Hobbema, Alta.

My dear Mr. Hoey:

I just received a letter from Rev. Father J. E. Pratt, acting principal of Ermineskin Indian Residential School, Alberta. Father Pratt informs me that all the repair work ordered last spring has been done and that the school is, in consequence, in much better condition.

There is still available out of this year's appropriation for this school the sum of $2,400. It is now proposed to use this amount for the construction of a new classroom and manual training building. The plans are now being prepared by your engineer at Banff. It is estimated that the new building will cost about $5,000 and it is hoped that the balance required will be made available by the department.

The repairs made to the school would enable the principal to accept more pupils and he would like the pupilage to be increased from the present figure to 160.

The general condition of the building would require the presence of a night watchman during the 10 school months. I know that the present regulations of the department only allow salaries for six months of the year. Would it be possible to make an exception for this school? The principal as well as the staff would feel greatly relieved of responsibility if the school were allowed to have a night watchman for the full school period.

It would be appreciated if you would ask your agent to make a new inspection of this school and its buildings, with the idea of suggesting what measures should be taken to safeguard the lives of the inmates in case of fire. The principal suggests adding fire extinguishers to the present fire fighting appliances. But you may wish to have your agent's advice on this point.

I hope that you will give these various requests of the principal your early attention.

Yours very truly,

J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.
