Dear Sir:

Re: Ermineskin Indian School,
Hobbema, Alberta.

I beg to submit the following report on work done at the above school.

Repairs and Renewals:

In further reference to my report of June 10th, numbered paragraph -

(1) Under all that portion of the floor above the basement except the northern (1/3) part,

when the old "Y" joint was removed from the ceiling over the basement, it showed the original floor joists in place. These were all logs set on the bank on, hewn on top to receive the floor and morticed into 10 x 10 fir beams, one in top each basement wall and one supporting post near the center of the building. These old logs were quite badly decayed. From 5 to 10 feet of the west end of those that originally rested on the west basement wall were completely rotted away.

A complete new system of floor joists, 2 x 12 on 12" centers, was placed in this section. These joists were supported near the center line of the building on 6 x 12 beams resting on 6 x 6 posts approximately 9' apart. It was very tedious and difficult to remove the old logs, especially without disturbing the flooring or classes being held in the rooms above.

(2) Reference last sentence, Page 1.

Three beams, in addition to those originally placed along the center line of the building, were placed under the floors supporting the second and third floors in the central section of the building. For some unknown reason, the central beam system running north and south, instead of being in the center of the 69' distance between the east and west basement walls (19'6"), was approximately 17'6" from the east wall and 21'6" from the west. The floor system supporting the second floor, over the main large classroom in the central one-third of the building, was strengthened by placing a 6"x12"...

T. S. Mills, Esq.,
Chief Engineer,
Engineering & Construction Service,
O T T A W A.
placing a 6" x 12" beam under the west or long portion of the floor span and carrying this beam on 6" posts approximately 9' apart. Similarly it was found necessary to place a second 6 x 12 beam directly in line with this beam but on the floor above and supporting the west part of the floor system on the third floor. It was not found necessary to place an additional supporting beam wherever under the east or shorter floor span a 6" x 12" beam was placed supporting the west portion of the second floor, over the girls' dining room.

(3) Reference last sentence.

Wherever found to be unsound, the old posts were replaced with new ones. Additional posts were added on the third floor. The entire central beam and post system was raised with jacks to the proper level and all posts were placed on new concrete footings. The 2" x 6" used in the floor systems of the building as reported in my original report was caused by the main supporting 6" x 6" central posts sinking into or bending the old rotten wooden floor log joists of the basement.

As mentioned above the central beam system above the basement was spaced 21.5 and 17.5 feet from the west and east basement walls respectively. But the beam system in the basement, and supporting the first floor, was exactly in the center of the building. Therefore, the posts supporting the second storey were not supported on the main central 10 x 10 beam of the basement but either on a log joist, approximately 2 feet east of the 10 x 10 basement beam, or on a short log bridge between two log joists. One such bridge had failed, allowing the posts to fall 4" to 5"; another has sunk into a rotten floor log joist. The new central beam and posts in the basement were placed in the same horizontal plane as the posts supporting the second and third floors.

(4) All floors were levelled where economically possible.

(5) A new fir floor was laid in the first grade classroom east of the kitchen on the first floor. New "V" joint was placed on the ceiling over the bread room, and over the medicine and charm room in the basement.

Two small rooms were partitioned off for sleeping quarters for the sisters from the extreme south basement rooms. Small closets were built in this same basement room to hold shoe and clothing supplies. Old "V" joint was used mainly for this work.

A small canned fruit room was partitioned off just north of the stairway into the basement from the girls' dining room.

A stairway leading from the sewing room on the second floor to the girls' dormitory on the third floor was enclosed with new "V" joint and provided with a door.

(6) The entire main building was given two coats of paint outside. The roof also received two coats of stain.

All outside verandahs and fire escape stairs were levelled up, strengthened and repaired where necessary.
A new well was drilled near the main building. This well was fitted with a new electric pump, automatic pressure controlled. It pumps into a 2000 gallon tank. This pressure tank, when filled to the maximum cut out pressure of 65 psi per square inch, will contain by volume one-half air and one-half water (1000 Imperial gallons). The pressure tank is connected to a 1-1/2" supply line through a valve and leading through two risers, each of 1-1/2" diameter to four fire hose connections on each riser, or two fire hose connections on each floor. Between the maximum cut out pressure of 65 psi and the minimum working pressure (tank nearly empty) of 35 psi, a quantity of 1000 Imperial gallons of water would be available for fire at an average pressure of around 45 psi per square inch.

A test was made to show service through a 50-foot length of 2" rubber fire hose and a 1/2" nozzle at a maximum pressure of 35 psi per square inch. At this minimum pressure, the hose would throw water as high as the top of the roof of the main building from a position on the ground outside the building.

A connection was made from the old well (about fifty feet away) to the pressure tank. The old well was also fitted with an automatic electric cutout and starting switch and had the pump jack repaired. As the hook-up now stands: All pumps operate at 65 psi. When pressure drops to 45 psi, the pump on the old well (No. 1) starts operating and continues until the pressure reaches 65 psi.

If the pressure be lowered to 35 psi, the pump on the new well (No. 2) will cut in and continue pumping until the pressure reaches 65 psi. Both pumps could be operating up to 65 psi and after Pump No. 2 cuts out at 55 psi the pump on well No. 1 would continue up to 65 psi. Ordinarily Pump No. 1 will suffice and it will be only on days of heavy draft, such as Monday washday, or in case of fire, that the pressure will be reduced low enough (35 psi) to cut in Pump No. 2.

Each well, singly, on test supplied approximately 5 to 6 gallons per minute. The two pumps working together supplied approximately 6 gallons per minute. During one week's observation, except on washdays, Pump No. 1 supplied the needs of the school by pumping from 12 to 14 hours per day, or at about fifty percent capacity.

An outside concrete room, connected through to the basement by a small doorway, houses the new well and pressure tank. This room will keep warm enough to keep tank or well head from freezing in cold weather by warm air entering through open door into basement.

A trench six feet deep was dug and one-inch pipe laid therein connecting pressure tank with laundry.

The work commenced September 16th and was completed November 26th.

Sir:

In reply to yours of the 16th Nov. 1938, no file No. regarding the new building that the Rev. Principal desires to erect at the Ermineskin Residential School.

I took your letter to the Rev. Principal and discussed its contents fully with him and allowed him to have a copy to forward to Rev. Father Routhier, Principal of the Oblate Order here.

I am enclosing a copy of the reply from Rev. Father Routhier to Rev. Father Pratt regarding this. It is translated from the French language, therefore does not read grammatically, in English.

Rev. Father Pratt has had plans prepared for this new building. This plan calls for a building 40'x60' with class rooms on the ground floor, the basement to be used for recreational and vocational training, the second floor to remain unfinished.

I am enclosing a quotation from the Imperial Lumber Co., Wetaskiwin for the material for the building which amounts to $415.00 and Rev. Father Pratt asks that the Department pay $2400.00 of this account and the balance will be paid from the $2600.00 being allowed him by Rev. Father Routhier. Rev. Father Pratt assures me that the remaining $225.00 will be ample to pay for labour and gravel if he is allowed to do the work.

There is one discrepancy I notice in this, there is no allowance made for heating this building, installing fire-fighting equipment and that seems to me to be a large item although Father Pratt assures me that he can finish this building ready for occupation for the $5000.00

Sir:

I have on hand yours of the 19 instant, and may I say that it was really a complete surprise to me when you requested me I had sent in the invoices from the Red Deer Singer Sewing Machines, and this in good faith.

When I received late last Summer the two Tailors' Machine, immediately I found out that they were too heavy for the purpose of training the young girls in sewing, and this as often requested by your Dept. At home they will never use a tailor machine and it is why I have tried to exchange them for lighter ones believing that it was O.K., and the Red Deer Sewing Machine Manager agreed to this transfer.

As to the last two items mentioned in your letter I had never in mind that the Dept. purchase them for us and although figure it is of course I believe we must have bought vouchers for the Sewing Machines. I am ready to pay for the two items mentioned because the Reverend Sisters for the new dresses had to come downstairs every time when pressing the dresses, and these articles are only for the use of the "everend Sisters in charge of the girls.

I apologize for not first applying to the Dept. for this exchange believing strongly that it was O.K., as far the Company would agree to do so. I also mentioned to our local Indian agent that I was to exchange them giving for reason that first I never called for Tailors' Machine but for ordinary Machines as these tailors' machines are too heavy and useless for the girls to press and sew.

Certainly if I had to pay at this time for Sewing Machine I would not have bought three at the time as my means would not allow me such an expense. I could only have done it on installments plan. If I have to pay for them, my only resources are to return them and pay only for the two Electric Irons & equipment.

Believe me, Sir, I acted in very good faith and never thought to go over the authority received.

Here I try to give to the girls the real training and with the big tailor machines the training will be a false one as they will never have them at home when their machines are replaced by new one we give them away to our Ex-Pupils, when getting married and are glad to have them having worked with them at the school. Also next Summer after our new addition being completed I will have a new place for a Sewing Club for the Ex-Pupils.
I inspected the Ermineskin School on the 21st and found everything in good order. Rev. Father Pratt is converting the upstairs rooms of the laundry building into an older boys' dormitory, which will be in charge of a man, and the children now living in the basement will be moved upstairs into the dormitories and the laundry machinery moved into the basement. I am glad this is being done as I was never in favour of children living in this damp, dark basement.

Alfred G.B. Lewis,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

Please find enclosed four copies of receipted statement of building material for the proposed addition to the Indian School at Hobema. I trust that you shall forward us immediately due to the amount stated in the recent letter to the acting principal.

You will realize that in building such an addition, a dire necessity, we are going to considerable expense, probably to the extent of between $5000.00 and $6000.00 above the amount furnished by the Indian Department. For several years many of the pupils have been confined to the very unsanitary basement as a bedroom. Also owing to the increased number of Indians on the Reserve, we have had as many as twenty children over and above the number for whom payment was received from the Department. I trust that you may see fit in view of the increased space available in the future to raise the rent for 160 children at Hobema and if at all possible that the government may assist us in paying at least a part of the debt incurred by the new building.

I wish also to notify the Department that it is my intention if you approve to name Father Edouard Rhéaume, principal at Hobema, succeeding Father Moulin, and Father Georges Latour, principal at Duck Lake, succeeding Father Delmas. Both Fathers Moulin and Delmas are going out next year and these two much younger men have, I believe, the very finest qualifications to serve in the capacity of principals. I would wish that Father Rhéaume's nomination become effective immediately and Father Latour's on April 1st.

Thanking the Department for its assistance in the past and trusting that all will turn out well,

I remain,

Yours very Truly,

H. Routhier O.M.I.,
provincial of Alta-Sask.

P.S. We had given instructions that these statements be sent on through Mr. Lewis, the agent at Hobema, but by mistake they were sent to the provincial bursar at Edmonton who was away for two weeks and came back only today. Owing to limited time I am sending them on directly.

Dear Sir,

As requested in a letter from Mr. Mills under date of March 16th, concerning reported unsatisfactory operation of new water system at Bruneckin Indian School, I visited this school on March 23rd and made a thorough inspection of the layout and adjustment of pressure tanks. I operated both wells singly and both pumps at the same time. I found the installation to be operating entirely satisfactorily.

1. There is an ample supply of water in either well. The man who operates the pump, Mr. Barry, reports that it is only necessary to run six or eight hours per day to supply their needs. The system is therefore not using 50% of the available flow of the wells. The water supply is therefore satisfactory in all respects.

2. The pressure tank, piping, and air and pressure gauges were in good condition and operating satisfactorily.

3. Both pumps and motors were operating satisfactorily.

4. In endeavouring to ascertain what had caused Nathan Pratt to complain as to the operation of the installation I was informed by Mr. Barry that:

Mr. (Mr. Barry) had changed the operating range of the pumps so that both ranged between a pressure range of 45 to 65#, instead of one pump operating between 45# to 65#, and one pump operating between 35# and 50#, as the heading was for, and as I had it adjusted when I left in November. (See my letter of November 26th 1920, page 3). This change was made by Mr. Barry apparently on his own initiative, in order to lessen the time each day that the pumps were running. After he made this change one of the old rods broke in the old well and one of the small rod couplings broke in the new well. These pieces were repaired and the pumps in both wells have given no trouble since.

Mr. Barry reported that he had trouble with one of the pressure switches. I examined this switch which was the one I set originally to open at 55 pounds and found the spring had been tightened so that the switch did not open until a pressure of 65 pounds had been reached and that a loose wire connection probably made when they were trying to adjust it, had made a rough contact. I requested

Mr. Betty to ...............

G. M. Walker, Esq.,
Supervising Engineer,
Engineering & Construction Service,
Banff, Alberta.
Mr. Berry to clean the contact points and return the switch to its original cut out pressure of 50.

The pumps have 1,1/2" cylinders on a six inch stroke and each will pump approximately 3/4 gallons per minute, or roughly 200 gallons per hour. This small size of cylinder was selected especially so that in so far as was possible the pump would not take out water faster than the water would run in the well. Cylinders too large cause much trouble with air locks as has been experienced at the Gleichen School.

Father Pratt evidently considered the pumps were delivering water too slowly or wanted to cut down the pumping time so they changed the hookup as described above, to have both pumps working all the time instead of one pump working all the time and the other pump sitting in only when the pressure fell to 32 pounds as originally adjusted.

On March 30th I again visited the school and accompanied by the agent, Colonel Lewis, the new Principal, and Mr. Berry, gave the layout a thorough inspection. Everything was found to be in order and working satisfactorily.

The hookup suggestion as submitted by a local plumber was found to be unnecessary as no water hammer was heard even when both pumps were operating at high pressure.

In conclusion I would point out that the adjustments controlling the operation of these installations should not be changed without the advice of some person who thoroughly understands the installation and would realize that there was nothing wrong with the installation that could not have been overcome with proper maintenance of the layout in its original adjustment. It can be expected that, occasionally an old rod or weak coupling will go, but this is strictly under the heading of maintenance, the rod might not have broken had the adjustment not been changed.

Faithfully yours,

W.H. [Signature]
Assistant Engineer.

I very much regret that the Department has not seen fit to increase the grant for Hobbsma for at least 175 children. There are practically 200 children of the Catholic faith on the reserve who should be in the school; the school is taking its limit by having 167 children in the present year refusing the school through lack of accommodation. I fear that if nothing is done here you will be forcing the Catholic children to go to the Protestant school at St-Albert and possibly preparing a dangerous issue. I shall later send in a detailed report on the situation unless something is done to remedy the very serious difficulties that will be met otherwise. I know that the Department has tried to be fair, and possibly meets objections from the Government owing to the enormous armaments program, but I do trust that you will help us solve this very serious problem of accommodation at Hobbsma.

Sir:

I have to report that I held a fire drill at Ermineskin Residential School on Tuesday the 16th Inst., after the pupils were in bed. This of course was done with the knowledge & permission of the Rev. Principal.

I was well satisfied with the drill, which of course was unexpected by the pupils. Fire hoses were run out & the building cleared of pupils in four minutes from the time the alarm was first given. Both pupils & teachers deserve every credit for the display. There was no panic, though two of the very young girls were a little upset, but everything else was orderly & the discipline perfect.

I wish to report however on the alarm system. When the alarm was given, I with the Rev. Principal was standing in the building & it was impossible to hear the gong from where we were. I would recommend that a large gong be placed outside, on the wall of the building, where it could be heard by everybody concerned. I am positive that had the children & sisters been asleep, no one would have heard the alarm in its present condition.

As there is no electrician in Wetaskiwin, I am unable to get an estimate on the probable cost of changing the present system. The nearest electrician is in Edmonton.

SPECIFICATIONS FOR HOBEMA MISSION SCHOOL

PIPES AND FITTINGS: All pipe shall be full weight, standard size, and best quality, or sizes noted on drawings, straight, true, and round, with full cut threads. All fittings shall be of best quality case iron, screw fittings, free from imperfections. Unions shall be installed wherever required and necessary. Where reduction in size of pipes occur, reducing fittings shall be used instead of flanges. Reductions of more than one size in steam mains shall be made by eccentric reducing couplings.

The ends of the pipes shall be reamed and filed, and all burrs removed from the interior of same. All joints shall be iron to iron joints tested steam tight and properly provided with expansion for expansion when installing all pipes. All necessary drips must be installed where required. Where local conditions require that a steam pipe be raised and dripped that shall be done even if not so shown on plans.

HANGERS: All piping shall be supported or hung in a secure and approved manner. Pipes at ceiling shall be suspended by means of approved iron hangers in a neat and substantial manner.

FLOOR FLANGES, SLEEVES: All openings thru ceilings, floors and partitions must be at least one-half inch larger than the outside diameter of the pipe and the pipes are to be kept fro the woodwork by approved floor sleeves and nickel-plated floor and ceiling plates.

PIPING: The piping system shall be installed generally as shown on the plans. All steam tappings in boiler shell be used, each connected full size of tapping into a steam header from which all steam mains shall radiate. The steam header must be dripped to the return header at boiler thru an equalizing pipe of liberal size. The steam mains shall start with high points at the boiler and shall be graded in direction of steam flow with a fall of one inch per ten feet in ten feet. All lateral branches or spring pieces to risers and radiators shall be taken off top of steam main at forty-five (45) degrees, and shall be graded back towards the main with a fall of one-fourth inch per foot.

The end of each steam main shall be dripped in the manner indicated on the plans.

All horizontal steam supply branches, such as spring pieces to risers, offsets in steam risers and runouts to radiators, therefore necessarily must drain in a direction opposite to the steam flow; thus in each case be installed one size larger than the vertical pipes to which they connect, unless otherwise shown on plans, and must be graded with a fall of one-fourth (¼) inch per foot. If such horizontal connections exceed eight feet in length, special attention must be given to their grade, and where the vertical pipes are one and one-fourth (1¼) inches larger on less the horizontal pipes must be made two sizes larger when not otherwise shown on plans.

The return piping shall be installed as shown on the plans; shall be graded in the direction of flow with a fall of one-half (½) inch in 10 ft. toward the boiler, and shall be entirely free from sags or pockets. All branch connections are to be made into the top of same at 45 degree angles. The return piping is entirely independent of the drip or bleeder piping, and is to be connected to boiler only as hereinafter specified.

RISERS: Risers are to be run concealed or in the open according to the desire of the owner, providing the Owner or Architect gives due and timely notice to the heating contractor when the building is being erected and will provide a place for said pipes when concealed. All reduction in riser sizes must be made at floor line or ceiling below. All risers must be properly supported and anchored.

All concealed piping must be capped or plugged and water pressure of at least 15 pounds applied and all leaks made tight when pipes are installed.

The radiator connections shall be run in floor construction wherever possible, each shall be taken off so that the expansion of riser can take place without lifting or tilting the radiator, or tapping any pipe so as to permit an accumulation of water.
RADIATOR TRAPS AND VALVES. Each direct radiator shall be provided with a Thermostatic Radiator trap of suitable capacity installed at the return outlet, said outlet to be at low point of the radiator; and with a radiator valve installed at inlet connection located at top of the radiator.

RADIATION. All radiation shall be installed as shown on the plans. Radiators located in front of windows shall be of such height that they will not extend above the window sills. All radiators shall be of hot water patter and provided with top capillary for inlet connection and with a one-half inch eccentric bushing in return tapping. All air valve tapplings shall be plugged, and radiation shall be wall under windows, in corridors and in basement. The radiation to be of a type approved by the Owner.

GUARANTEE. When the apparatus proposed to be furnished is completed in accordance with the conditions hereof, the Heating Contractor must guarantee it to circulate steam throughly through every radiator in the system without noise, with the steam pressure on the heating mains not to exceed two (2) pounds gauge.

If after this apparatus is installed, accepted and paid for, any part completed in strict accordance with the drawings and specifications or the true intend thereof, shall fail to accomplish the guaranteed heat by reason of any defect developing within the period of the full heating season due to faulty material or poor workmanship, the Heating Contractor shall remedy such defect at his own cost within a reasonable time after notice. The defects as above used shall not be construed as embracing such imperfections as would naturally follow improper treatment, accident, or the wear and tear of use or the improper working of this system if the chimney is not of sufficient size to create a good draft.

FINALLY. Nothing herein contained can be construed to relieve this Heating Contractor from making good and perfect work in all usual details of construction, and he will be held responsible to provide and furnish all materials, and to do all the work and labor, and to bear all expenses incident to the satisfactory completion of the work embraced in this specifications.

EXTRA:

Connect to the present heating system; run steam and return mains through the building; supply approximately 900 sq. ft. of radiation and divide up into 13 units.

GALVANIZED WROUGHT IRON PIPE

All galvanized wrought iron pipe shall be of make approved by the Owner, of standard weight, without evident defects, p lay welded for all sizes, true as far as practicable. The threading for all joints shall be well out of a sufficient length and carefully cleaned of all burrs, fins etc.

A liberal supply of union joints shall be provided to make repairs in screw joint work easy. Said union joints to be located where in the Owner's opinion they will be found to be most useful.

All joints of galvanized iron to Cast Iron Pipe shall be screw.

All joints in cast iron work shall be caulked solid with clean spun oakum and run with pure new bar lead at one pouring, using not less than 12 oz. of lead to each 1" diameter of pipe. The lead shall be caulked solid with proper caulking tool and hammer and finish flush with tip of hub.

All joints to lead pipe shall be wiped.

All joints to lead pipe to cast iron, brass or steel, shall be made brass ferrule properly wiped to lead. The ferrules to be caulked into the iron pipe and screwed to brass or steel as above specified.

VERTICAL:

All vertical piping shall be perfectly plumb and offsets eliminated as far as possible.

HORIZONTALS:

All horizontals shall be laid with proper even slope not less than ¼" to the foot toward point of drainage. Vent pipe to have as great a rise as possible, satisfactory to the Superintendent.

FITTINGS:

All fittings for cast iron shall be of cast iron corresponding with pipe in weight and quality.

Fittings for wrought iron shall be of best quality...
Note that fittings shall in all cases be of that type which is best suited for its intended use so that the result will conform to the best plumbing practice. In cast iron work all connections shall be made in the form of single Y's and lead shall be carefully laid in all curves.

**Supports:**
All piping shall be firmly supported in place. Vertical cast iron pipe shall be supported once in each length or pipe by means of wrought iron clamps with two extension bolts extending into masonry or two screws screwed into wood.

**Cleanout Plugs:**
Throughout the soil and waste system there shall be a sufficient number of cleanout plugs and cleanout hand holes in easy accessible places so that every portion of system can be properly cleaned out. These shall also be open to each concealed trap in the waste system placed so as to reach traps; in general one is to be located at least at one of all horizontal runs, preferably at high end. Wherever necessary on account of the length of horizontal runs, place additional cleanouts so as to conform to the foregoing requirements for rodding out of the entire system.

Every fixture throughout the building must be separately trapped and all traps must be vented, by branches specified in City Bylaws.

**Cut Off Valves:**
The entire supply system shall be equipped with cut offs so that each branch or portion of the system can be cut off and where same cannot be drained by regular fixture outlets, it shall be equipped with cut off and drain. Unless otherwise specified they shall be of wheel handle, brass body pattern and correspond in finish with the pipes they are on.

**Use of Pipes:**
Galvanized iron pipes shall be used for all water supply and galvanized wrought iron pipe shall be used for all vent piping unless otherwise specified.

All horizontal waste pipes from fixtures concealed in floors must be lead pipe. (This will be insisted upon.)

**Work Included:**
Reference to general plans will show location and number of fixtures required. Furnish all main stacks, drops, supplies soil and vent pipe etc., necessary to effect first class work. All pipe work to be concealed in floors and walls unless otherwise noted or directed by the Superintendent.

**Soil and Waste System:**
Connect all fixtures in the building to the soil and waste system. The pipe shall be in accordance with all previous requirements under heading of "Piping." All work shall be done in the most direct manner possible in accordance with the best plumbing practice and as approved by the owner, except noting that the size of connection to each fixture is established by the fixture specifications and that the pipes are to be gradually increased as more are added, said increase to be in all cases acceptable to the owner.

**Painting:**
All exposed pipe included in this contract, including fittings, etc., shall be painted by the owner.

AGE T'S REPORT ON HORBEIA AGENCY JUNE 30th, 1939.

I visited the Armineskin school on the 14th and inspected children in the classrooms. All appeared in good order. Elder girls were in dormitories repairing mattresses and sewing. All looked well and healthy. All children that had homes to go to were let out on the 30th for their annual holiday. A few children were being kept in school on account of having indifferent homes to go to. The new addition to the school is slow on account of rain. The exterior is now finished and the roof on, so that the work now should progress faster. It will be ready for occupancy when school opens on 1st September.

A. G. B. Lewis,
Indian Agent.
Dear Sir,

Being warned by the Rev. Father Plourde, of the return of the 5% on the per Capita Allowance, I cannot help thanking you personally and in the name of the Ermineskin School.

But as a favor pushes one to ask for an other, I dare again to solicit your help for the increase of the per Capita Grant for the number of our children which will be 200 in the coming September, and we are now receiving Grant only for 140.

After my being here for 3 months I notice a great difference with the other schools of the Indian Department. It is a pity to see the old building at Hobema. Everyone is living in hope for a new school.

Lately with the help of Colonel Lewis Indian Agent for the Hobema Indian Agency, we succeeded to obtain a few acres of land from the Indians, to improve the school farm. We are also going to start soon to put on a working shop for vocational training for our big boys. Actually our school teacher is following a course of physical training, at Mount Royal College, Calgary, to be able to lead the young generation of Indians in physical development.

We want to work in cooperation with the Indian Department for the success of our school and for the welfare of the Indians.

Now as the new addition to our School is nearly completed, would it be allowed to me to make another request for beds and school desks.

1. Beds: 18 beds size 4 1/2 ft.
   18 beds size 5 ft.
   18 beds size 6 ft.

2. Desks: One for teacher and 40 school desks (medium size)

With thanks once more

I remain Yours truly,

Ed. Rheume O.M.I.
Principal.

FIRES TO BE INSTALLED:

PLUMBING: OUTSIDE DRAINAGE:

Owner shall provide necessary drain from septic tank, sewer to building.

SOIL PIPES:

Soil pipes to be of 4" medium heavy cast iron to run from end of underground rising out through roof and to have proper 6 lb lead collar at roof line turned into the joints of pipe and properly sealed to roofing. All to be made complete and to have necessary Y connections for all fixtures and joints to be made with spun oakum and molten lead and made perfectly air and water tight and all pipe to be properly secured in place.

WATER PIPE:

Outside water pipe to be 1" lead pipe. Inside water pipe to be galvanized iron water pipe. Inside will provide 1" valve with compression stop and waste. Run water pipe to supply water to all fixtures as hereinafter specified, also to range boiler and heating boiler. All piping to be concealed where possible and all exposed portions to have flanges. Leave off hose connection where directed with pet cock drip. All pipe to be graded so that entire system can be drained or equivalent.

NOTE:

All fixtures throughout to be back vented in accordance with the Town and Provincial By-laws.

STOP COCKS:

Supply lines to bathrooms and toilets to have separate stop cocks on water lines on basement ceiling.

BATHS:

Provide and fit up where shown on plan, cast iron enamelled baths, 5' long, with compression bath cocks, china indexed handles for hot and cold water, N.P. supplies, N.P. "U" trap and overflow, N.P. chain and rubber stopper. Bath to have 3" roll rim or equivalent.

CLOSETS:

Provide and fit up where shown on plan, closets with wash down bowl, heavy oak tank with fittings, oak seat hinged reinforced seat less cover with N.P. supply pipe. Provide heavy lead waste with floor flanges or equivalent.

SINK:

Wash sink 4' long, cast iron enamelled roll rim, and to be hung on concealed brackets and to have N.P. strainer, approved cocks and iron sink traps.

OWNING PIPE:

Pipe to be covered against frost where necessary.
FLOOR DRAINS:
In toilet room and where shown provide floor drains with screwed brass covers.

TESTING PIPES:
All pipes to have water and smoke test, before trenches are filled to satisfaction of the Owner.

PIPE HOSE:
Three (3) sets of hose, with 1/2" valves, racks, 25' of 1/2" hose and nozzles.

All fixtures are to be vented in accordance with Town and Provincial By-laws.

HEATING BOILER:
The main and returns to be connected to the present heating boiler in the old building.

RADIATORS:
Provide and fit up radiators as shown on plan with cast iron screw nipple of plain design and each to have quick opening valve with wood wheel handle and N.P. extra, approximately 900 sq. ft.

PIPE COVERING:
Cover pipe where necessary in danger of frost.

PIPING:
Contractor shall provide all piping in accordance with the plans or as directed. If any alterations are to be made Contractor shall submit piping plans to Owner for approval. Radiators of 60 sq. ft. or over to have 1" valves and under 60 to have 1/2" valves. Valves and risers to have an area greater than the combined area of the valves they supply.

PAINTING:
Painting to be done by Owners.

PLATES:
All pipes at floors and ceiling to have N. plates.

GUARANTEE:
This contractor shall guarantee the satisfactory operation of all work and apparatus installed under this contract and shall replace forthwith at his own expense any part which may fail or prove defective within a period of 12 months from the final acceptance of the completed contract; always provided such failure is not due to improper usage or ordinary wear and tear.

HANGERS:
All mains of basement to be supported from slab on adjustable iron hangers.

Sir:

In reply to your 112-1-1 of the 16th September last, I beg to inform you that I have at last been able to get an electrician to come to the Ermineskin Indian Residential School and give me a price for a new fire gong and two break-glass alarms in the new dormitory connecting with the central alarm system.

Mr. Chapman of the Chapman Electrical Co. of Wetaskiwin came down accompanied by the salesman of Northern Electric Ltd., Edmonton, and recommended that a No. 8790 "Benjamin Weatherproof Howler" be attached to the outside wall and connected with the present alarm system installed in the school. Also that 2 break-glass alarms be installed in the dormitory of the new building, this also to be connected with the present fire alarm system.

The present alarm system in this school is totally inadequate in so far as gongs are concerned. Each dormitory has a small bell similar to a doorbell and when it rings, it makes about the same noise and distance and children who are rather tired, asleep, or ill, would hear it. The male staff whose duty would be to assist at a fire, live in a house about 50 yards away from the school building and would never hear an alarm. This howler would be heard for a quarter of a mile.

I am also asking for a No. 66 "Edwards Transformer", so that the system can be operated from the Calgary Power Company energy instead of the present dry cell operation. Last week the dry cells were dead and consequently there was no power for the fire alarm system. This is too dangerous to be allowed to continue.

I am attaching Form 37/1 in the amount of $46.79 for material, and a Form No. 37/1 in the amount of $30.95 being the cost for labour, and 20% to cover the cost of freight, express and handling charges, which is the customary charge.

I have done this as Mr. Chapman put himself out to come down here and give us an estimate on the job. I would like to see him get the work so I will make each regulation come under $50.00 although I explained to Mr. Chapman that if he came and estimated on the work, he may not necessarily get the contract.

The only firm on the list in Wetaskiwin shown as Electricians, is Templeman Bros., and they do electrical work on pressure pumps, etc., and not house wiring. They are really plumbers.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

Being told by Rev. Fr. Plourde from Winnipeg that it is time to send our requirements in Ottawa, I beg to ask your Department for help in our farming outfit.

I have already asked Colonel Lewis, Indian Agent at Hobbema, for a Hammer Mill and swings for the children's play ground, which I consider most important for the school at the present time.

But with the reducing of the Per Capita Grant the problem becomes greater for us. Since these last two years, we have done our best to improve our farm at the Ermineskin Indian Residential School. I must mention that not a single acre of land was ever given by the Indian Department for our School. After many difficulties we finally succeeded in obtaining 80 acres of land from the Indians.

Everything was done in regular form with the Indian Agent. We now have 160 acres in all.

Farming is emphasized in our big boys' training. Our girls milk the cows, take care of the chickens and look after the garden.

In order to be able to give our boys the farm training they most essentially need, I am asking your department for the most important implements required on a farm: gang plow, a disk drill, a cultivator and a harrow. A machinery shed is badly needed and our root cellar needs repairing.

Being fully aware of the difficulties of the present times, we cannot however forget the training that our children require in order that they may become good and useful citizens of Canada. You may rest assured dear Sir, that we are doing our utmost towards the education of our Indian children, both for their moral and material good.

I remain yours very truly,

Ed. Rhenume O.M.I.

Sir:

Rev. Father E. Rheaume, O.M.O., Principal of the Ermineskin Residential School at this Agency has sent the following letter requesting that the Department supply Battleship Linoleum for the floor of the Recreation Room which is in the basement of the new wing.

The size of this basement is 40' x 60' with a corner partitioned off approximately 5' x 20' which is used as a bathroom and lavatory.

There is a little better than $400.00 left in the 1940-41 vote for necessary repairs at this school, and the price quoted to cover this floor for "D" Grade Dominion Battleship Linoleum @ $1.85 per sq.yd. is approximately $738.00

The floor of this recreation hall is of cement and the younger boys play in this room all winter. It is very dusty and damp and the youngsters are always on their knees; consequently their stockings and pants have no knees in them in a very short time.

I would recommend that authority be given to expend this sum on linoleum, if the appropriation for this school has not already been expended.

The Principal of the Ermineskin Indian Residential School has brought to the attention of the Department the condition of the fire escapes.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge your 112-1-5 of the 24th instant, advising me that the Principal of the Ermine-skin Indian Residential School had brought to the attention of the Department the condition of the fire escapes.

I inspect this school, when pupils are in residence, once each month, and at each inspection pay particular attention to the fire escapes and hose, and was more than surprised to receive your letter informing me that the Principal had notified the Department that a condition existed, which required attention, in the fire escapes. He did ask, however, that the buzzer system be extended to the new wing of the school, which I have included in my 1942-43 Estimates.

I interviewed the Principal today, and he informed me that he has never made any complaint regarding fire escapes at his school, but that he had referred the matter of the buzzer to Reverend Father Plouard, O.M.I., and he is of the opinion that the Reverend Father must have misunderstood his letter, and had written to the Department complaining about the condition of the fire escapes.

All buildings used by pupils and staff are equipped with the pole system of fire escape, and the children and staff are practiced in fire drill and ladder interwale, either the Principal or myself turning on an alarm. There is, however, a counter-balanced stairway at the rear of the building, which is used by the girls in fire drill, the boys using the poles. These stairs are made of wood, with rope attached to the counter-balance weight, which lower the stairs to the ground in case of a person being on the top. They seem to be adequate, but could be dangerous in case of a fire taking hold and burning through the ropes and catching the stairs, which as I have remarked, are of lumber construction, albeit, but when the building got to this state other means of exit would have to be found anyway.

If it is the intention of the Department to install a buzzer at once, I will get prices and submit them for your approval, please.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Alfred G. B. Lewis,
Indian Agent.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of March 15th, and in reply to your last paragraph beg to report that I had Mr. Paulson, the manager of the Revelstoke Sawmill Co., Ltd., and Mr. Sorenson, the local bricklayer, inspect the lumber at the Kutenai Indian Residential School, and find that in certain buildings from top to bottom, it was their opinion that the lining of the building with a fire-proofing material was out of the question. As due to the constant vibration of the walls caused by the pulley shaft which runs the machinery, it would not remain in position, and would cause endless trouble after it had been attached. It was first thought that Gyp-rock Plaster Board might be suitable.

After a thorough examination of the building, it was decided that the building would not present a serious fire hazard if the old chimney, one of which had been torn down to get at the fire which had broken out in the woodwork behind it, were rebuilt; as that apparently was where all the trouble originated. The constant vibration of the building had shaken the mortar loose between the bricks, allowing the fire to escape through the chinks, and eventually set fire to the woodwork. Only one chimney is now available for the different stove and boiler-room buildings, and the large number of stove pipes criss-crossing through both the upstairs and downstairs rooms makes it dangerous as it is at present, and it is recommended that the old chimney be rebuilt, and proper tile chimney lining installed, and that the chimney flue be built up from the floorboards all the basement up to its present position, which is resting on a wooden shelf, and that they be left standing by themselves and not built flush to the wall. If this is done, it is considered that this building will not be any greater fire hazard than any other frame building used for laundry purposes.

The Revelstoke Sawmill Co., Ltd., in co-operation with Mr. Sorenson, who is the brick layer and plasterer on our preferred list, have offered to do this work for the sum of $53.00. Copy of their tender is attached hereto, and I would ask that if the Department is agreed to do this work, that I be given authority to have the work done at the price quoted.

Dear Father Rheaume:

Dear Sir:

We would be very much obliged if the Department could consider giving us a grant for the construction of a hog house.

At present we have no hog house. All we have are old buildings that are practically falling to pieces, poorly located, cold in winter and under water at spring time.

With our present accommodation 3 sows only can be cared for, and only summer hogs can be raised. Last winter due to poor location one complete litter was lost. If we had a proper piggery winter hogs could be raised, and as hog prices are higher in winter than in summer this would help us out on the financial side as well as providing meat for our school.

With the help we now have (i.e., boys working at barns as part of manual training) we could increase our stock of 3 sows to 12 or 15. This would give better returns and help balance market supply.

I have taken the initiative of sending tenders to two lumber yard firms at Wetaskiwin, our nearest business point, which I enclose herewith. I thought my action would save valuable time later on, if the Department would grant our request.

I hope the Department will look favorably on our request, and at the same time this will enable us to do our share in full out war effort of providing bacon for our Armed Forces, and the needy of war stricken areas.

Yours very respectfully,

[Signature]

L.C. Schmidt, O.M.I.
Principal.

Dear Father Schmidt:

FIRE PROTECTION AT ERMINESKIN SCHOOL.

Now that winter is at hand I beg to submit the following report on the Fire Equipment at the above School:

Fire Hose.

A number of hose in the building were broken at the connections. These are to be repaired immediately. Some of the hose leaked at the valves and couplings. These require washers and this will also taken immediately. Metal fire extinguishers are missing and glass balls containing a red liquid are substituted. These I consider inadequate.

Fire Alarm System.

Fire alarm bells in the dormitories are too small and are inefficient, larger bells should be installed. There is no alarm system in the new dormitory. There is no alarm system in the Sister's house and the Priest's house. They would not know if a fire occurred but would have to be informed by messenger. The electric Siren installed here is not loud enough for this purpose. In this connection, I have tried for over a year to induce the Electrician in Wetaskiwin to come down and give me an estimate and suggestion for improving this system. He informs me that he has more work than he can handle and does not know when he can come.

General.

There are two doors in the girls dormitories, which open on to the same platform. These open against one another, blocking the exit from the smaller girls dormitory. This particular escape is a wooden stairway and should not be used for fire escape purposes. I believe a thorough inspection by a competent engineer should be made of these buildings.

Alfred G.B. Lewis
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
December 7, 1943.

Mr. A.G.B. Lewis, Indian Agent, Hobbema, Alta.

I have your recent letter with reference to fire protection at the Ermineskin Residential School. I note that you are arranging for repairs to the valves and couplings of the fire hose. If you consider more fire extinguishers are required, please let me know the number that you think should be purchased. You should make another attempt to have the electrician give you an estimate on the cost of installing an additional fire alarm system. We will endeavour to have the school examined by an official of the Surveys & Engineering Branch as soon as possible, but, owing to shortage of staff and the many duties that they are called upon to perform at the present time, it is doubtful if this visit will occur in the near future. In the meantime you should take whatever action you feel is desirable to guard against fire hazard. I refer particularly to the two doors in the girls' dormitories which open on the same platform.

R.A. Hoey,

Your memorandum of December 7th last relative to the above was referred to our Engineering and Construction Service for attention.

Our Architect, Mr. Buck, has consulted Mr. Phelan by telephone regarding the matter and the latter furnished him with a copy of extracts from a letter from Indian Agent G. B. Lewis, giving further details.

R.A. Hoey,

Reference your 112-1-5 of the 7th December, 1934.

I beg to report that I have, in company with the Rev. Principal, made a further survey of the girls' dormitory and have arranged for "fire drill" as follows: First, permanently close the door leading out of the Sisters' cell in the N.W. corner of the Senior Girls' Dormitory. On the "fire alarm" sounding the bell, 24 children located in the Junior Girls' Dormitory will take charge of the juniors and lead them either to the outside fire escape on the east side of the building, or to the pole fire escape on the north side or any other exit we may be considered necessary to the occasion, as directed by the Captain in charge of the floor. Drill will be made elastic, and exits must be kept open in conformity with the position of the supposed fire. It is stressed that on occasion it may be possible to use the fire alarms installed in the Senior Girls' Dormitory, but will prevent "fire drill" from becoming stereotyped, and in case of a real fire the children will not expect to use the same exit, which may be cut off on account of flames from the floors below, but will use the exits as directed by the Captain of the floor.

These dormitories are in the roof and all windows are of the "Dorman" type. On the west side a verandah roof projects from the exterior wall level with the floor of the dormitory along the south half of the building, and along the north half of the building on the east side, which makes an installation of a fire escape in the Senior Girls' Dormitory if not impossible, a very arrangement undesirable in a building. This new arrangement, while allowing for the evacuation of the children to some extent, will work perfectly well when they have had a few drills. At a drill held by the Principal, the school was evacuated in three minutes. I am enclosing a rough plan of this floor to help you visualize what I mean.

I have written a letter to the electrician, pointing out to him the seriousness of not having an adequate "alarm" system in our school, and how much more important it is to ensure the safety of our children than that some individual should have light on his front porch, but so far have had no reply although I wrote over two weeks ago. Would it not be possible to obtain a "trinity" for this work, which would force this man to attend to this very necessary and urgent matter.

REPORT ON HOBHEMA INDIAN AGENCY

Ermineskin's R.C. School - is a very old building, entirely unsuitable, and in my opinion a dangerous fire hazard. If a fire were to break out in the middle of the night with the temperature below zero there is no doubt but that there would be a serious loss of life amongst the Sisters and the children. The place was spotlessly clean and the remodelled clothing and articles of handicraft were as good as anything yet seen.

J.K. Morris,
Welfare Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

The Reverend Principal of the Ermineskin Indian Residential School called on me today and said that he had received a letter from the Rev. Father Plouard informing him that a sum of money had been set aside for repairs and improvements to the school and that if he had not already been notified of the amount, to get in touch with his Indian Agent and get him to write the Department about it.

Rev. Father Rueux wishes me to ask if he will be authorized to spend the sum of $400.00 on the girls' toilet, which has been included in the 1945-46 Estimates, and the sum of $600.00 to build a granary, which was also included in next year's estimates.

Regarding the girls' toilet. The present building is very old and is falling down, the wood being rotten and it is not possible to prop it up as nails won't hold in the structure. It is the intention of the school to build a new toilet and install a flush system and connect it with the present septic tank. This will be more sanitary than the old earth closet now in use and in my opinion should be done as early as possible.

This school has extended its farming operations and the new granary is required to house the grain from the school farm.

Dear Sir:

There is at the Hobbema Indian Agency a Progressive Club. This Club was founded by Rev. Father Rheume O.M.I., an R.C.A.F., stationed overseas.

The objective of the Club is "Progress in every line", be it in relation to God, in healthful living, in the homes, on the farms or in the relations with fellow neighbours, all to tend towards the well being and the progress of the community.

The members of this club are taught that before they can progress they must first of all accomplish their fundamental duties towards God, towards their country, towards their immediate dependents and towards their fellow citizens.

It is not however enough to remind them what those duties are, we must help them in their struggle for improvement.

This is done:

A. By lectures! These lectures are followed by open discussion on a subject of actual and well proposed interest. By these lectures we aim to re-educate or continue the education of the members. By these lectures we aim to open their eyes to the deficiencies, to expose the defects and backwardness existing amongst them above all we try to make realize that they can achieve success as well as their white neighbours and that one day if they persevere in their efforts, they will be as good and as useful citizens as any of the other component parts of our Canadian nation.

B. Open forum another means of educating the members of our club is the discussion in open forum of a topic presented at the opening of a meeting. (no member knows what the subject will be till he hears it from the Chaplain) this is done in view of having the members grasp a subject at point blank range and be able to understand it, discuss it thoroughly without preparation and use it then have to do daily. This way of doing shows the Indian that he has an intelligence and that it has a purpose other than giving in blindly to everything without understanding.

These two first points may be considered as the more serious or intellectual activity of the club.

C. Another means of educating our Indians is Movies. Even though our Club has been in existence for only four years it has already felt the results of its good work. The Club has already organized different forms of entertainment some of which bring financial revenues which enables the Club to sponsor movies. The Club has purchased its own sound motion projector of $450.00 and has paid its first bill of $35.00. It can really be said that the good example of the members of the Club amongst which we have the two chiefs and two councillors is already making others take notice.

To-date all meetings of the Club have been held in either the boys recreation hall or in a class room at the Ermineskin Indian School, this way of acting has been found very unpracticable by;

Over.
Continued.

1. The school staff: If lectures are held during school hours some pupils are without instruction; if lectures are held at night the school ground becomes the meeting place of hooligans and disorder reigns in the dormitories.

2. Boredom for members: Most members enjoy and like to be interested but they are not so much interested in coming to club meetings and at the same time act as Sergeant at Arms to too many who flock around the school with aim of disturbing the school children, especially the big girls.

The movies are given every Monday night at the Hobema Garage, to-date much difficulty has been encountered with the man who actually runs the garage. This garage has been remodelled and is used exclusively for dances and shows when the Club first started holding shows at the Hobema Hall. Garage rent was $5.00(three dollars) a night, then the rent was raised to $5.00 (five dollars) a night; now it is up to $6.00(six dollars) a night plus 25% profits above the first $2.00(twenty dollars) the new hall was uncleaned(claimed the owner) after every show. Now a janitor has been appointed and a salary of $1.00(one dollar) has to be paid him. The promised eighty five dollars ($85.00) has been paid in rent to-date.

Faced with all these difficulties, the members of the Hobema Indian Progressive Club, have resolved at a regular meeting that a hall should be built.

Purpose of said Hall.

A. Band and council meetings, for which no fee will be charged.
B. Regular and extraordinary meetings of the Club.
C. Shows.
D. Wedding dinners and wedding dances, a fee will be charged by the Club for such gatherings.
E. All other dances will be held in the hall for which a fee will be charged.

Let it be noted that the Club has also resolved in one of its meetings that a Sergeant at Arms, member of the Club, shall be responsible for good order during dances and other gatherings in said hall.

The Hall is not being built by the management of the Ermineskin Residential School, the hall is built by the Club members themselves, each member has given a personal donation toward this end, the balance of the money comes from Club revenues, membership fees, show collections. It has also been resolved that no band, nor any member of the Club has any personal title to the hall, the hall is being built, owned and operated by THE HOBERMA INDIAN PROGRESSIVE CLUB.

Signed, Rev. Father L.C. Schmidt O.M.I.

AIRMAIL.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ontario.

In reply to your 112-1-5 dated February 19th, 1945, and your 112-1-5 dated March 8th, 1945 regarding a proposed building to be erected by the Hobbema Indian Progressive Club.

On receipt of your first letter I interviewed Rev. Father Schmidt who is responsible for this organization and he asked me to leave the letter with him and he would submit a written report. Before receiving this report I went with him when he had been on Sick Leave. Upon receipt of your "Airmail" letter of the 8th inst., I got the Agency Clerk to drive me up to the School. Rev. Father Schmidt had not yet prepared his report, but he promised to do this right away and I received it from him this morning and am enclosing a copy herewith.

As the report shows, the Hobbema Indian Progressive Club members have collected sufficient funds to purchase material with which to build a hall in which to hold their meetings and to exhibit their moving pictures. The construction work is to be done by the members of the Club. They propose to allow the four Bands at this Agency to use the hall for Band meetings, free of charge. This is a decided need; there is no place at this Agency that can accommodate the members of the various Bands at a meeting and it is necessary at present, to hold these meetings outdoors. They also hope to rent the building, for a small fee, for Indian wedding parties and Indian social events. With this revenue they expect to cover the cost of coal, light, caretaking and repairs.

This Club is doing good work, is undenominational and should be encouraged as it tends to take our Indians out of the rut in which they have lived for years and I heartily approve of the project.

I beg to report that a fire, of unknown origin, broke out in the boiler room, which is situated in the North end of the basement of the old dormitory and class room block of the Ermineskin Indian Residential School, just after midnight of the 16th and 17th April, 1945.

A Sister, who was sleeping in the class room immediately above the boiler room was awakened by the smoke and immediately turned on the alarm, and by prompt action of the male members of the school staff in running out the fire hose, we were able to confine the damage by actual fire, to the boiler room and the class room immediately above.

From an inspection I made this A.M. the main damage requiring repairs is as follows:

Boiler Room
1. Metal lath and plaster ceiling to be rebuilt.
2. New Asbestos cover on boiler.
3. New steam gauge and water gauge on boiler.
4. Renew joists where burned and found unsafe.
5. New sash and frames for basement windows.

Class Room
1. New flooring in north half of class room.
2. New base board in north half of class room.
3. New glass for several windows and doors.

Other Damage
Floor in the adjoining class room is badly warped owing to water and will have to be relaid. Some rooms will need re-decorating on account of smoke and water damage and other floors may warp in the near future. A small quantity of class room furnishing was damaged and will require replacement. Several windows will require re-glazing, and some cemented to floors has become unsound and will require re-laying. I would respectfully request that the services of an engineer of the Survey's Branch be utilized to estimate the cost of repairs to this building please.

I respectfully submit the following report on the first- Upon my arrival at the school the basement was so full of smoke that it was impossible to go down to discover the seat of the blaze, but a red glow in the smoke showed that the fire was in the boiler room, into which the staff assisted by Mr. McLeod, our Farming Instructor at Agency Head Quarter were directing two lines of hose. Later the fire started to burn through the floor of the class room, and a fire bucket brigade was organized among the older boy pupils, the floor torn up. In this way it was possible to keep the fire under control under the floor.

Smoke was now getting worse and we seemed to be making no headway and I decided to ask the assistance of the City of Wetaskiwin Fire Department, who are equipped with smoke masks and special electric lamps for this kind of work.

Over.
Fire Chief Dave Baker and four of his staff responded to my request and took charge and within one hour and a half had the fire completely out.

I give credit for this fire not assuming greater proportions, to the fire drill, which is regularly practiced in this school, where everyone has a job to do in case of fire, and knows how to do it, and the assistance cheerfully given by the Wetaskiwin Fire Department, to whom I would ask that the Department forward its thanks officially.

I also wish to report that the school was evacuated in five minutes, each pupil passing in front of the school with a blanket. When it was found that there was no immediate danger the elder pupils got clothing and bedding from the dormitory and the girls and smaller boys were billeted in the Church for the night, the elder boys were allowed back into the dormitory of the new wing after the fire was out.

Owing to the mess in the boiler room and windows being out, making it impossible to heat the building immediately, the Rev. Principal asked permission to allow the children to go to their homes for the balance of the week. Classes to resume on Monday, 23rd April, to this I agreed. I have Mr. Templeman, the plumbing contractor here to-day, testing the boiler and putting it into working condition, so that the work in cleaning up the rooms may be started immediately.

All of which is respectfully submitted, please.

[Signature]

Alfred G.B. Lewis,
Indian Agent.

Add: After making this report I went to the school to see how Mr. Templeman had found the boiler and I find that this building is covered by insurance and the adjustor is allowing for the complete removation of the damaged parts.

Re Sewage System, Ermineskin Schools.

Reference to the above file and your letter dated 30th Oct in which you ask for a report on the above for your information I attended to the matter yesterday and regret that I had not gone into the matter before, however just all cannot be done.

Please find attached a rough sketch which shows the detail compiled from actual observation and history obtained from the school engineer's memory, no records or blue prints are available or I don't for that matter if any ever made.

You will note I have numbered the outlets from the school #1,2,3&4 and have shown the details of each outlet handles. You will notice that No.1 line is exceptionally heavily loaded. The laundry disposal does connect direct with the sewer and passes thru both tanks. These tanks are not what I take to be septic tanks all the tanks are of cistern type with no walls or shipper, it should appear there is no disintegrating of the disposal. The laundry disposal outlet does not by-pass anything. The cisterns are of cement construction as noted on the sketch.

On investigating the sewer outlet which is one hundred and fifty yards from the pump of the school, was found to be in a very bad state of repair being blocked up with the summer's dead growth and general gathering together with an old roof slaved into the outlet that had covered the outlet "once upon a time". Father Labonte undertook the work of cleaning same out and the work is now under way and he is also going to erect a temporary cover to keep the outlet from freezing the winter.

In regard to recommendation, I would suggest that the present system be coaxed along this winter and between now and next 1st July an estimate prepared by a Sanitary Engineer as to what I would think an overhaul of the entire system. It is in the programme to have the sewage system of the hospital & nursing station of the Hobbema Indian Agency to be revamped this coming spring when I would suggest that a local contractor could do the whole job. It is my opinion that a Sanitary Engineer be consulted in the school case. If the dept. desire me to proceed with obtaining of the necessary data on a suitable disposal system for the school I would be only too pleased to do the same. The main thing as I see it is to have the work lined up and ready to go at the beginning of summer holidays.

For your information the boys dining room in the basement (where all the children's dining rooms are) was flooded last July from an apparent back up from the "A" tank.

At present the School have no way of emptying the sewage tanks except by bailling. I would ask for authority to purchase a sump pump (the same type was purchased for the Blue Quill's School) with hose connections at an approximate cost of $50.00.

For your information I have discussed this matter with the Principal of the School and he agrees with the contents of this letter.

With reference to the first paragraph of your letter, there is actually no functioning to the sewage system, the disposal runs directly thru all tanks and thru the sewer outlet, there are no settling tanks. In regards to my recommendations I have made above, I hardly feel capable of dealing with situation and in getting further information I contact capable authorities in Edmonton for further advice if the dept. so desire me to do so. I am of the opinion a good sanitary engineer should be consulted. Judging from the
from the sad experiences of our department in dealing with the sewage disposal of the Indian Agency, we cannot be too careful in getting all the advice available. Local soil conditions are none too good and disposal fields do not seem to work and septic tanks of suitable capacity connected to an effluent sewer seems to be the answer to the sewage disposal.

Further to this letter I would say that the Ermineskin School is in a poor state of repair and quite a dangerous fire hazard as you are aware, so one wonders at the advisability of a heavy expenditure on the present school. I am dealing with some requests for fire protection in another letter.

Respectfully submitted,

W.F.B. Pugh,
Indian Agent.
Hobbema, Alberta.

Re Repairs - Ermineskin School.

Reference to your letter of the 16th Oct. I regret my delay in replying to same, and at this time of writing I have not all the information that you desire.

In dealing with the second paragraph of your letter, in which you state that you are purchasing 2 sewing machines, 24 small desks and one teacher's desk, we are not quite clear if the cost of these articles is a charge against the $1250.00. I would appreciate hearing from you in this connection.

Re Drying Machine - for laundry, the principal obtained prices on a drying cabinet but they are much higher than he expected. My suggestion is that a drying cabinet be built with a heating unit and fan installed. This is under consideration.

Re Dough Mixer - the purchase is also under consideration and prices are being obtained.

Re Maple Flooring - I beg to state that in view of your letter I took the privilege of ordering from the Rawatstoke Lumber Co., Ltd., Wataskiwin, Alberta, 785 ft. of No. 1 maple flooring 13/16 x 12" @ $162.00 per m. $125,550 delivered. This was the only chance I saw of obtaining any flooring and the School Kitchen is in very bad need of being replaced. The above amount will just about complete the kitchen floor 17 ft. x 25 ft.

Shortly after Father Labonte took over the school last July the small girls' dining room floor was in very poor state of repair and had to be replaced; he did so at his own expense. He is asking if the sum of $135.00 could be charged against the $1250.00 and refunded to the school. If so, the floor in it was beyond use and I would much appreciate if the amount of $135.00 could be reimbursed to the principal. If so I will obtain his receipted account and forward the same to you.

In regards to the linoleum for the kitchen in view of the hardwood flooring being obtained for the kitchen, the principal might decide to make a switch of this, however, in view of good quality linoleum being hard to obtain at the moment, he would like time to see what could be done.

I regret my information is somewhat vague but we are working on the same and have in view getting plans made and forwarding the same to you.

Re Fire Protection Ermineskin School.

I beg to inform you that last week I gave the fire protection of the above school a close examination and I would point out the following:

1. The electric wiring is all outside wiring of the old type run with porcelain cleats, very little conduit used in the old building, this in itself is not all that could be desired.
2. The main fire escape of the old building which serves the older and young girls is a very rickety wooden fire escape attached to the main building and could be improved upon. In this regard I am getting a quotation on a steel Potter Fire Escape and will forward the same to the department.
3. Shortage of fire hose—it was fire hose that saved the school last April. Further fire hose asked for in this letter, also half dozen more Pyrene Fire Extinguishers needed.

The following is an outline of the fire hose needs:
1. Boys' Play Room: 50 feet long, should be 65 ft long so as to reach Boiler Room. This should give two hoses two boiler room.
2. Baby Class Room: (New Building) 30 ft long, should be 65 ft long so as to reach the following Class Rooms: Grade 1, 2, & the Big Boys Class Room.
3. Big Boys' Dormitory: 24 ft long should be 50 ft long so as to reach the stairs.
4. Small Girl's Dining Room: 20 ft long, should be 50 ft long so as to reach the Kitchen and Indian Parlour.
5. Big Girls' Sewing Room: 50 ft long, should be 65 ft long so as to reach Sisters' dormitory.

The above would make the purchase of 120 new hose 5 couplings, however, the Principal and I are both of the opinion that if the following are purchased—
Two 65 foot new hoses—130 ft complete 1½" unlined linen hose with brass couplings & two nozzles—
130 ft of hose at .65¢ per ft—$85.00
2 brass couplings @ $3.50 each—$7.00 (or 5 couplings—$17.50)
The hose that would be replaced by the new hose could then be added to existing hoses and three more extra couplings would be needed in addition.

The Rev. Principal is also asking for Six only hand operated Pyrene Extinguishers—1 qt size complete with charge and wall bracket at a cost of approximately $8.00 each—$48.00. I would concur in this purchase, this will give a total of 18-1 qt size hand operated extinguishers which are now located throughout the buildings.

At the fire last year a smoke mask came in very handy that was sent down from the City of Wetaskiwin Fire Dept., these cost approximately $26.00 each. However it is possible that the dept. have had experience with these masks and that you do not approve of these being supplied.

I would recommend an expenditure of approximately $150.00 to $175.00 for further Fire Fighting Equipment for the Ermineskin school.

W. F. E. PUGH,
Indian Agent

MEMORANDUM

14th January 1946.

Re: ERMINESKIN INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL
HOBBEMA, ALBERTA.

With reference to your notation dated the 29th ultimo on a memorandum to you of December 31st last from the Director of Indian Affairs regarding a fire escape for the above building; we are unable to furnish you with the report you request from information furnished.

The tender from the Westeel Products Ltd., of Edmonton, dated Dec. 4th, 1945, quotes a price of $986.00 for a Potter fire escape 80 inches in diameter with a drop of 12 inches. The tender states that the price is based on sketches and notes forwarded by the Indian Agent, whom, it is indicated, has suggested that certain operations involved should be carried out under his own control.

The Potter fire escape is a tubular metal unit, supported on structural steel legs and concrete footings. It is felt that a misunderstanding has occurred between the Indian Agent and the Westeel Products Ltd., since the drop to which reference is made is 18 feet 8 inches.

Before we can express an opinion on the cost, or comment on how the proposed fire escape meets the situation, this Service must be furnished either with copies of the sketches and notes prepared for the Westeel people by the Indian Agent, or shop drawings from the tendering firm supporting their quotation.

It appears from the tender that the matter has been handled entirely by correspondence. The Indian Agent should arrange to have representatives of firms tendering on the fire escape visit the school and familiarize themselves with the situation, before submitting their tender, which should include the cost of cutting and patching walls and any other incidental operations required, such as the installation of lighting facilities as well as supplying and installing the fire escape.

It is recommended therefore, that Indian Affairs have Indian Agent Pugh review the matter with the Westeel Products Ltd., and obtain a revised tender from them on the basis we have outlined. This, with complete information on how the fire escape is to be installed, should be forwarded here for our examination.

If possible, a tender should be obtained from at least one other firm for this work.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys & Engineering Branch,
Dept. Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

AGENT'S REPORT FOR THE QUARTER ENDING DECEMBER 31st 1945.

XX XX XX

Education. The Ermineskin School visited a number of times and a sewerage report also fire report made on the same, but there is nothing to be added to the education. Personally the more I think about Indian education the further I bog down. One wonders when you see all the newspaper talk, parliamentary talk of committees to investigate this and that, if only some of our critics could live on the reserves it would be their education, on the other hand a shake up of our education system might do a lot of good. It is to be hoped that if any committee is formed to investigate the Indian set up that they will be able to spend considerable time at some of the reserves and schools. I am sure I have visited the kindergarten class and what or how those Sisters start in teaching these young Indians from 7 to 11 years of age not able to speak English is really something, the first year is just nowhere with them.

Family Allowance.

I think is doing good for the Indians and the children appear better clothes, but it is making a tremendous increase in the office work, it is never ending the checking and rechecking, of the families.

XX XX XX
