Re: Sewage disposal
Ermine Skin Indian Residential School.

On April 9th and 10th Mr. Cornish accompanied by Mr. W. H. Ball, Junior Engineer, made an investigation of the sewage system at the above school. A sketch plan of the main building basement was made and the soil and drainage lines located as closely as possible. The outside lines were also located and the elevations noted at points where pipes were accessible. Duplicate prints of plans showing the existing system are being forwarded under separate cover.

The complaint of the school authorities is that on several occasions line '1A' passing beneath the concrete floor slab of the small boy's dining room has become plugged and water has been forced through the pipe joints to flood the floor. Water also has backed up from line '1A' through the connecting lines '1B' and '1C' and so onto the bakery floor. Line '1A' is an old 4" tile pipe not in good condition. It carries the discharge from 8 water closets and 3 sinks in addition to the laundry drainage. The diameter and material of pipe in lines '1B', '1C' and '1D' is not known but they are apparently unused and not connected to any fixtures.

As far as could be ascertained the remaining drainage pipes within the building are adequate for existing fixtures and no trouble has been experienced with them. The only exception to the above is the pipe from the kitchen sink which is frequently plugged with grease despite the installation of a grease trap under the sink. The kitchen line has two clean-outs in the section under the storeroom floor.

Line '1A' is in poor condition and in any event should be of cast iron construction under the building. It is recommended that the section of this line within the building be replaced by a 4" cast iron pipe. This will entail cutting and replacing the concrete floor.

The disposal system outside the building is as shown on the accompanying sketch plan. Drainage from the main building passes through lines 1, 2 and 3 to a single compartment tank 'A'. In such the inlet and outlet pipes are only 1 foot above the tank floor. It seems fairly evident that the backing up in line '1A' is caused by accumulation of solids in the tank above the outlet of line 1. The discharge from tank 'A' passes down 6" tile line '1A' to tank 'C' from which it runs out into the depression of an old watercourse now generally dry. Tank 'C' has apparently had two compartments at some time but the center partition and part of the end wall have crumbled or been knocked out.

T.S. Mills, Esq.,
Chief Engineer,
Surveys & Engineering Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.
Drainage from the engineer's house and work-shop passes through a recently built single compartment concrete tank (B) patterned after tank 'A'. The discharge from tank 'B' passes down a recently built 4" tile line 'B') to join line 'A'. Drainage from the priests' house runs to an old log cribbed tank with the outlet running to the water course into a lower section of which tank C discharges. This log tank is ten years old and due to cave in at any time.

Existing tanks A and B cannot function as septic tanks nor can they be converted for use as septic tanks. Tank C was probably originally intended as a septic tank but is now beyond repair. Two schemes are possible for sewage disposal as follows:

1. To convert tanks A and B into inspection chambers by filling with concrete to the pipe level and to install a new septic tank just below the junction of lines A and B. Tank C would be filled in and line A taken through it to discharge into the water course.

This scheme would not provide for diversion of laundry drainage around the new septic tank. The estimated cost is $2,000.00.

2. In order to divert the laundry drainage around a new septic tank as located in scheme 1, it would be necessary to run a 4" line from the laundry to below the tank location. To avoid the extra length of line paralleling line A it is proposed to install a new septic tank, large enough to serve the school, just below tank A and bring a 4" laundry drain through the building in the same trench as the line recommended to replace existing line 'IA'. This laundry drain would discharge into line A below the new tank. With this layout it would also be necessary to run a soil line from the laundry to connect the water closet in the laundry building. Sewage from the work-shop and engineer's house would be handled by a small septic tank immediately below existing drains and through tank C to discharge into the water course. This scheme is recommended and is estimated to cost $2,300.00.

Sewage disposal from the priests' residence does not fit into either of the above schemes and it is recommended that a separate small septic tank be installed near the site of the existing log tank. The effluent from the new tank would discharge into the water course.

To recapitulate, it is recommended that:
1. A 4" C.I. pipe be installed to replace existing line 'IA' and be extended by 4" tile to the laundry to pick up the water closet there.
2. A new tank be installed near existing tank A to take sewage from the engineer's house and work-shop, the school building.
3. A new tank be installed near existing tank B to take sewage from the priest's house and work-shop.
4. A 4" line be installed to bypass the laundry drainage around the larger new tank.
5. Existing tanks A, B and C be filled in and existing lines piped through them.
6. A new septic tank be installed at the priests' house.
effluent discharging directly to the water course.

The approximate estimated total cost of the above six recommendations is $2500.00.

Supervising Engineer.

Memorandum

Re: Sewage Disposal
Ermineskin Indian Residential School

Referring to your notation on a copy of a memorandum from Indian Affairs dated November 16th, 1945, we are now in receipt of a report dated April 24th from Mr. Walker in Banff dealing with suggested improvements in the sewage system for the above residential school.

Two copies of the report and one copy of each of the two accompanying blueprints are attached. The blueprints show the present layout of the sewer system at the school.

It is recommended that the following work be done to renovate this sewage disposal system:

(1) A 4" cast iron pipe be installed to replace existing line LA and be extended by 4" tile to pick up the laundry water closet discharge.

(2) A new septic tank be installed just below existing tank A to take the sewage from the school.

(3) A new septic tank be installed near existing tank B to take sewage from the engineer's house and workshop.

(4) A 4" line be installed to carry laundry drainage in same trench with laundry sewer and connect to line A below new tank.

(5) Existing tanks A, B and C be filled in and sewer lines piped through them.

(6) A new septic tank be installed for the Priest's Residence to discharge direct into the water course.

The estimated cost of this work is $2,500.00 and we suggest that this work be undertaken at the same time as the sewage scheme at Hobbema Indian Agency.

Chief Engineer.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Re: Sewage Disposal - Ermineskin Indian Residential School - Hobbema, Alberta.

With reference to your memorandum of August 8th last and previous correspondence relative to the above, I may say that although $1,000 from 1946-47 funds was made available for this project by Indian Affairs Branch our Engineering and Construction Service was able to secure delivery before April 1, 1947, of materials to the value of $179.48 only.

In the meantime prices of material and rates of wages have both increased and it is now estimated that the work estimated to have cost $1,000 a year ago, will now cost $1,200 in addition to the $179.48 already spent. This work would be comprised of the following:

(1) A 4" cast iron pipe to be installed to replace existing line 1A and to be extended by 4" tile to pick up the laundry water closet discharge.

(2) A new septic tank to be installed near existing tank B to take sewage from the engineer's house and workshop.

(3) A 4" line to be installed to carry laundry drainage in same trench with laundry sewer and connect to line A below new tank.

(4) Existing tanks B and C to be filled in and sewer lines piped through them.

(5) A new septic tank to be installed for the Priest's residence to discharge direct into the water course.
The location of the above items is shown on the blue-prints forwarded with Mr. Mills' memorandum of May 22nd, 1946.

If it is your wish that the entire project recommended in Mr. Mills' memorandum of May 22nd, 1946, and which was then estimated would cost $2,500, be completed during the present fiscal year, it is now estimated on account of increases in the cost of materials and wages that the cost will be $3,700 in addition to the $179.48 already spent.

Will you kindly advise me to what extent you wish this project proceeded with during the current fiscal year and the amount of money that will be made available.

Work on Project No. 2 commenced Monday, November 17, 1947, the contractors, Haddow and Maclean Ltd., of Edmonton having just completed the installation of a sewage disposal scheme for the Department at the Indian Agency. All arrangements for disrupting the regular school program had been made with the school authorities at an earlier date.

It was necessary to tear up three layers of wooden flooring before exposing the concrete floor in a portion of which it was broken up in order to get at the underlying sewer line. All the work was done by hand labor which proved difficult and slow. At the east wall of the building, an excavation down the wall was made and by tunnelling under the foundation, both lines were placed. Outside excavation was hindered by the fact that only half in the ground so that at the west wall the tunnelling was done from the inside and both lines placed as required. However, such connections as were necessary were made inside the building as shown on the accompanying plan. It will be necessary when further work is carried out at this location, that the outside connections be made and those already made on the inside be slightly changed.

Clean out structures were installed in the system as a precaution against further inconvenience. Care was taken in the laying of the C.I pipe to see that the maximum amount of fall was obtained from below the foundation on the west wall to the 6" tile drain in place below the east wall. The necessary connections for all incoming lines and appurtenances were made with the exception of the underfloor drains for which permission had been given to leave disconnected. All pipe joints were inspected and passed as satisfactory. The portion of the concrete floor which was broken was replaced and it was decided by the school authorities to use the concrete floor rather than replace the wooden flooring.

Cleaning up operations were satisfactory and the work was completed and turned over to the school on November 29th, 1947.

The weather in .........
The weather in general was cold and snowy but considering the lateness of the season it was only to be expected.

Throughout the course of the work, the school authorities were most co-operative and are anxious to see the rest of the work completed. They suggested that further work should best be done during the summer holidays when the school is relatively inactive. In all, the portion of the work done by the Contractor was carried out in a satisfactory manner.

Attached please find a statement of all expenses incurred during construction of Project.

Respectfully submitted,

Re: Repairs to Sewer System
Bymineskin Indian Residential School, Hobbema Agency

With reference to your 112-1-5 (W.T.I.) of January 27th, 1948, I beg to submit this report as supplementary to that of Mr. J.F. Hunt, Engineer.

The sewer disposal pipe from the laundry and the one from the rest of the building above the basement enter the drain at the same point. Concern as to its efficiency in sewage removal at this point was expressed by the Rev. Father Adam, principal of the school. However, it is unlikely Mr. Hunt would have made this connection without considering all the possibilities. No blocking has occurred at this point to date.

As you are aware, the school is very antiquated at the best and when repairs of this nature are done, they are just patchwork. There is a great need for a new school.

In Mr. Hunt's report you will note that three layers of flooring were removed, exposing the concrete floor. This floor was so rotten that replacement of it was impossible once it was interfered with. This floor was in a basement room which serves as a dining room. It is a very dark and dingy room and not a very enticing place in which to eat. The wooden floor that was removed was not very satisfactory and I believe the cement is the better of the two.

As Mr. Hunt states, the portion broken was replaced but there is still a considerable area of the floor that was hidden by the wooden flooring which I believe should be smoothed over for the reason that small holes or cracked portions of a cement floor are not satisfactory from a sanitation point of view. The principal of the school has indicated that he intends to have this done.
Everything possible was done by the contractors and Mr. Hunt to see that the school routine was not disrupted, and the staff expressed appreciation in this regard.

I concur with Mr. Hunt that the work was done satisfactorily under difficult conditions.

H.H. Woodsworth,
Superintendent.

Memorandum:

Re: Sewer System - Ermineskin Residential School, Alberta

Referring to the memorandum from Indian Affairs dated January 26th, 1948, we are now in receipt of the following from our Banff office under date of March 15th:

"The vital item is the construction of a properly designed septic tank to replace existing tank "U" which serves the main school building. Until this is done there will be no cure for the condition originally complained of, that is, the backing up of sewage from the present tank to the drainage system under the basement floor. We have minimized the effects of this action by replacing the old tile line under the basement floor with cast iron pipe, but we have not yet attacked the cause. The cost of a new tank will be approximately $2500.00 or an approximate total of $800.00 will be used in purchase of material. If Indians Affairs are limited to an expenditure of $1000.00 per year on this work I do not see how this important item is to be built. It would not be feasible to purchase the necessary material out of this year's funds and hold it for a year, as there is no adequate storage for cement. In any case an amount of approximately $200.00 must be made available for the labour charge of installing the tank, which must be done in one operation."

The estimated cost of this tank is based on the records of last year's work. Originally this tank was estimated to cost $1500.00 but prices are now much higher and there might be a difficulty in persuading a contractor to go into the reserve for such a small project unless the price is high. It would thus seem that a minimum of $2500.00 should be provided this coming fiscal year. If completion of the entire project is desired, a total of $3500.00 would be required. The funds required for the additional work after the main septic tank is completed would thus be $3500.00 - $2500.00 which is $850.00.

We should be pleased to know what funds Indian Affairs will be able to provide for the coming year.

Chief Engineer.

Memorandum re Water Supply, Ermineskin Indian Residential School,
Hobbema, Alberta

Received April 4, 1949

This Indian school is located on a farm near the small settlement of Hobbema, Alberta, on the Calgary - Edmonton highway. It is owned and operated by the Roman Catholic Church and at present it has 175 pupils and a staff of 22. The school was started in 1894, and some of the buildings still stand.

Water is pumped from two wells to an 1800 gallon pressure tank which supplies the distribution system. Well No. 1, located in the laundry, is 250 feet deep, is not cased, but the 2-inch pump cylinder stands well above the laundry floor. This electrically-operated pump discharges 3 to 3½ gallons per minute but after several hours of pumping decreases to half that amount. Well No. 2 is located in a separate room with the pressure tank. It is approximately 400 feet deep, has 4-inch casing extending well above the floor, and a 2-inch pump cylinder. This well also produces 3 gallons per minute but has a limited supply. Water in well No. 1 is pumped from a depth of 150 feet and in well No. 2 from a depth of 250 feet.

Attached hereto is the analysis of four samples taken for bacteriological analysis. The positive sample is unexplainable unless the bottle was contaminated, so further samples will be taken.

The attached chemical analysis shows the water to be of negligible hardness and has a Chloride content of 2.0 PPM. The soda content does not make it disagreeable to drink. Some natural gas rises with the water, and gas from a cock on the pressure tank can be lighted.

Conclusions and Recommendations

The water supply at this school appears to be of good chemical and bacteriological quality.

The small discharge from each pump necessitates almost continuous pumping with at least one pump, necessitating extra attention and low efficiency with the small discharge. The two present wells are located quite close together and the one probably draws water from the other.

It was noticed that there was no fire protection for the building and the present supply could hardly cope with even the smallest fire.

Recommendations

It is recommended that the water supply be increased by the drilling of another well.

Stanley S. Goff
Sanitary Engineer, District No.8.

Dear Father Plourde:

As you very well know, the situation at the Ermineskin Indian Residential School, Hobbema, Alta., is far from being very bright, but with God's help, I hope to be able to make a success of my work.

I have at last found time to devote to letter writing, and my first letter is to ask for more of your time and help, may I take this first opportunity to thank you for your generous help in the past and ask your assistance for the future.

The first request is a very special grant, which you will realise is very much out of the ordinary.

The potato and garden crop at the Ermineskin Indian Residential School has been a complete failure this year. We have reaped enough potatoes for about a month. Re: Ermineskin Indian Residential School
Potato Shortage

Attached find a letter received from the Reverend Father Schmidt Principal of the Ermineskin Indian Residential School, and also a copy of a letter sent by him to the Reverend Father Ploude, who will contact you.

After receiving this letter, the Principal's request for assistance careful consideration was given to the case. The matter was discussed with Mr. Battle, Field Agent from Mr. G. H. Gooderham's office, during a recent visit here. There seems to be an urgent need for assistance on this situation. I beg to report as follows:

1. Along with the surrounding area of northern and central Alberta a serious drought accompanied by unseasonal frosts, occurred, which according to the local press, is the worst in forty-five years.

2. Of the potato crop, there is a yield very little better than the seed sown; only enough for one month's needs for the 160 pupils in residence at this school.

3. Although there has been a considerable increase in the per capita grant, it is still not enough to cover operating costs of this school. Revenue obtained from farming operation supplement the Departmental grant and enable this school to operate. This farming operation is carried on on the Ermineskin Reserve with land owned by Band and leases with members of that Band. No other Band contribute land although they send pupils to this school. The per capita grant, is I believe, lower than other similar Residential Schools.

4. During the past two school year, 1947-48 and 1948-49, the Ermineskin Indian Residential School cooperated extensively with the rehabilitation of T.B. patients of this Reserve. Children of T.B. families recovering from the Charles Cassell Indian Hospital were accommodated before others, although in most cases, special food and attention was necessary. Families of relief cases are also accommodated first.

5. Obsolete equipment, buildings, inefficiency and lack of land all contribute to high operating cost of this school. This office, during the past two years, has realized the situation and made efforts to correct some of the problems of administration. In this I believe we have the full co-operation of the Reverend Father Schmidt who has inherited this year this tremendous administration problem. The farming catastrophe is however, beyond the scope of this office able to handle. This office therefore respectfully submits a plea for aid. I suggest that a solution may be to raise the per capita grant. It is hoped the Department will be able to solve this emergency at the school. It also should be pointed out, if the pressure for food in this emergency was not on the school, it would be on the Indian parents who are this year of crop failure, may not be even able to feed themselves.

REFRIGERATION:
Present refrigeration unit only keeps temperature at 40 degrees F. What would be required is a freezer so as to freeze meats and keep them frozen. Actually we must store all meats in the Locker Storage in Wetaskiwin. This of course is an expense, plus the travelling back and forth to Wetaskiwin for frozen meat.

TABLEWARE:
A complete line of plastic drinking cups and plastic tableware sufficient for 175 pupils and a staff of 25 would be very much appreciated for the Ermineskin Indian Residential School. The tableware being used now are of granite-ware, and are very old and chipped.

FIRE ESCAPE:
A-The present fire escape system at the Ermineskin Indian Residential School should be renewed by the funnel type fire escape. Today a wooden stairs strapped to a wooden wall is the main fire escape for three dormitories:
1- Big girls dormitory
2- Small girls dormitory
3- Small boys dormitory.

B-At the north end of the small boys dormitory there is a steel pipe fire escape. This pipe is accessible only by crawling through a window before reaching the platform of the fire escape.

At this particular fire escape, a door-window should be installed to give quicker exit for the small boys.

C-Automatic door latches should be installed on all doors leading to the fire escapes, the automatic push-latch would be the most practical and safest latches to be used, these latches are made up of a bar of steel held by a coil spring, the simple pressure of the hand or the pressure of the body on the steel bar throws the door open. These automatic push-latches would also eliminate the ordinary knob door sets. With the knob door sets, they easily opened from the outside, and here may I state that strangers were found in the dormitories on different occasions in the past. With the automatic door-latches, no door could be opened from the outside.

SCHOOL:
The Ermineskin Indian Residential School, is a very old and out dated building, a large number of Indian children are still unable to attend school due to lack of school accommodation even though the Ermineskin Residential School, the Hobbs Indian Day School and the Montana Indian Day School are now in operation. While the Leslie Butte Day School is new, this will not solve the situation, but will help solve it. A solution to the acute school accommodation could be, the building of dormitories, modern dormitories, close to the Ermineskin Indian Residential School. These dormitories could be heated with a central heating system, and class rooms could be added in the future. The present residential school could be used for class rooms, manual training rooms and dining rooms.

The building of dormitories would solve the fire hazard and the old school building could accommodate larger class rooms, while awaiting the building of modern school rooms.

NEW BARN:
The present barn is very old and very cold in the winter time. The milk cows suffer greatly during the winter months in this barn, and this causes lack of milk for the school children.

A herd of 15 milk cows can be handled in this old barn. This proves very insufficient to provide milk for the school children.
NEW HOUSE

The housing accommodation at the Ermineskin Indian Residential School for employees is very acute.

There is only one small house available for the hired help; this house is very small, three rooms downstairs, one kitchen, living room and bed room. The attic is converted in sleeping quarters for 6 children. This house is now occupied by Mr. Baril, whose work around the school consists in janitor, boiler mechanic, carpenter, truck driver, electrician and all other work that has to be done in a hurry.

The farmer, Mr. Houle, lives in quarters above the work shop. The upstairs of the work shop was converted into living quarters due to lack of proper housing for the hired help at the school.

The reason for asking this house is that I would move Mr. Baril into this new house and move Mr. Houle, the farmer into the small house, and use the upper floor of the work shop for what it was intended for; a work shop for the boys. We are planning on starting the manual training for the boys at the Ermineskin Indian Residential School, but we are faced with lack of space.

The new house should have, a basement, a kitchen, living room and one bed room downstairs, and an upstairs with three bedrooms and a bath room.

ELECTRIC DISH WASHING EQUIPMENT:

An electric dish washing equipment would be appreciated at the Ermineskin Indian Residential School. The present set up consists of big enameled pans set at the end of each table. It is very difficult to picture the clear clean water after 10 plates have been washed. A sanitary angle could be considered here.

WELL

A new well is also needed at the Ermineskin Indian School. We are now using two wells, at the same time, and both do not prove satisfactory. We are faced with a water shortage every winter.

Yours truly,

Rev. L. C. Schmidt O.M.I.

Re: Ermineskin Indian Residential School

With reference to a letter from C. A. F. Clark of December 15, 1949, to Superintendent of Indian Education, copy received. I note Major Clark recommends a modern dormitory that will at least eliminate the danger of a night fire destroying the lives of the 180 children in this rapidly deteriorating ancient building. I would recommend that such dormitory be constructed in such a way that it might be used ultimately as a classroom block. I foresee that the residential school as operated at present should gradually evolve into something better. In my opinion a residential or boarding school will always be necessary as long as there are Indians who come from nomadic, broken or no homes, for which there is no solution other than residence.

I know Mr. Neary will agree that a school without qualified teachers is only a school in a limited sense. As there are no qualified teachers employed at the Ermineskin Indian Residential School, this institution cannot truly be called a school.

The Reverend Father Schmidt, Principal of the Ermineskin Indian Residential School, informs me that no qualified teacher can be employed in the immediate future due to lack of finances at this institution. It would appear also that no prospects of education on a proper level in the foreseeable future are possible unless a start is made in this direction. I would therefore, recommend that the teachers, whether clerical or not, be employed as Civil Servants and detached from the administration of the institution as far as is possible.

I see no justifiable reason why children within one half mile of a Residential School are forced to live in residence as is now the case. Using the present facilities as they are, we can assure a satisfactory school system can be evolved serving both day and residential pupils.

Re: Administration
Ermineskin Indian Residential School

Further to my letter of December 22, 1949, I beg to inform you that I have had further conversation with Reverend Father Schmidt, Principal of the Ermineskin Indian Residential School, especially on the subject of qualified teachers and general administrative setup of the institution.

The purpose of my suggestions, which it is hoped will ultimately lead to a solution of the problem of school facilities for the 100 or more children not yet in school in this Agency, is to provide such facilities and include qualified teachers. I therefore respectfully submit the following proposals which I know will receive the co-operation of the school administration:

1. The immediate use of the facilities of the school as a start to operate at least one day school class room. This, I visualize, would include a civil servant teacher appointed by the Indian Affairs Branch and preferably a Sister of the order as present operating the school. This would solve housing and other problems for the teacher. I am assured such a teacher, fully qualified, could be hired. If necessary, I would make this day school a separate institution as existing schools from the residential school. It is realised, of course, such an arrangement would only be theoretical but by such an arrangement a qualified teacher might be employed and still conform to departmental policy, of instituting a day school system.

2. If a start was made in this direction, I foresee a continuous evolution whereby all children able to go to day school would ultimately do so and those unable would be cared for in residence. The end would, I am sure, conform to policies outlined by the department. The favorite aspects of a residential school system could be retained and the features of a day school system developed. All rural areas are now consolidating their schools, and it would certainly be folly, especially at Hobbema, to build scattered day schools when good roads and buses could very easily bring all children in from at least the Ermineskin and Samson Reserves.

Memorandum

Re: Ermineskin Indian Residential School, Hobbema

We have Major MacKay's memorandum of December 12th last bearing your marginal notation of December 15th, requesting a recommendation on the attached tenders. These have been examined and you are advised as follows.

It appears that an existing installation, about which we have no information whatever, is to be converted into a Freezer Room and Cooler Room of which the dimensions, volumes, capacities, temperature accessories and development of plant are not specified. Therefore the tenders received are based on different design requirements and cannot be compared on this account.

We further note that none of the tenders quoted a fixed price for the work. This is quite in keeping with the fact that no set schedule of the equipment required was specified, and that while many items are desirable, they are not essential.

In view of these considerations and the fact that the selection of a tender rests on the Indian Affairs Branch decision as to the extensiveness of the plant required, we cannot make any recommendation.

The file on this matter is herewith returned as requested by the Indian Affairs Branch.

"C. Victor F. Weir"

DIRECTOR

Ermineskins Residential School

As I have previously advised you, this school is about as old and rundown as the Cariboo residential school at Williams Lake. Mr. Woodsworth has seen the plans for the projected new dormitory-classroom block at Williams Lake and feels that it would be very satisfactory for the Ermineskins school. Dear Mr. Neary:

Your Superintendent Mr. Woodsworth has contacted the Reverend Oblate Fathers of Edmonton to obtain the property of the Ermineskin Indian Residential School, both buildings and land, for the Government.

Whilst there is considerable doubt as to the ownership of the land on which the buildings were erected some years ago, the fact remains that the school and its out-buildings have always been considered the property of the Oblate Fathers. It is also true, and we admit it willingly, that your Department has at all times been very generous in keeping the school and the out-buildings in proper repair by contributing substantial amounts for that purpose every year. On the other hand, the Oblates have had a staff of both Fathers and Brothers who have worked in this school very faithfully in the interest of the Indians and in a secondary manner in that of the Department of Indian Affairs. I believe that these services should be recognized in a substantial way.

Hoping that you will consider the above favourably, I remain,

Yours very truly,

J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.

Re: Potatoes, Ermineskin Indian Res. School

Attached find a copy of a letter from the Reverend Father Schmidt, Principal of the Ermineskin Indian Residential School concerning his expenditures in the purchase of potatoes for the school, and receipted invoices.

The children at the Ermineskin's School
are apparently well cared for, but it seems to me they
are not getting the proper food, when seven or eight
cows are supposed to supply milk for 140 people.
The Department should insist on the proper amount of milk
being supplied to the pupils at our Indian schools.
I think that in many cases we are giving medical attention
for illness, when the illness could well be avoided.
I am sure Dr. Stone will agree with me that when Indian
children are not properly fed they are very susceptible to
tuberculosis and other complaints.
Ottawa, February 25, 1930.

Sir:

The attention of the Department has been drawn to the inadequacy of the milk supply furnished for the daily use of the pupils of the Ermineskin's Indian Residential School. As you are aware, the Department expects that these institutions will supply milk to the children in sufficient quantities, as it is considered one of the most important items of the children's diet. We are informed that the school has at present only 7 or 8 cows, from which the entire milk supply is obtained for the daily use of the pupils and staff.

You should take up this matter with the Principal and inform him it is expected he will arrange, if there are not other cows in the herd that will soon freshen, for the purchase of a further number of milk cows sufficient to provide an ample supply of milk for the pupils' daily requirements. A request has been made for an increased pupilage as from April 1st next, but, unless the Department is assured that an adequate supply of milk will be available, favourable consideration could not be given this request. After fully discussing the matter of a good milk supply with the Principal, you should inform the department of the action he intends taking to increase the number of milk cows and in furnishing an adequate daily milk supply for the pupils' requirements.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. G. Askew, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Hobbema, Alta.
To the Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs.

Dear Sir,

The Indian Agent Mr. Askey gave me knowledge yesterday of a very surprising letter received recently from the Indian Department.

It has been reported that we did not give an adequate supply of milk to the pupils of the School. When the Inspector Christianson from Regina office was visiting our School at the end of January, he asked how many cows we were milking and our man said: Two.

It was true but the Inspector did not put any other question, nor make inquiry; it would surprise me very much that a man of his standing would have reported thus only after that one question.

The fact was we had one cow that was fresh and the other was giving wet milk. Two more could have been milked but scarcity of green feed would have made it hard for them. About a week or ten days after his passage we had 3 cows that calved and one recently. We have now an average of 20 to 24 gallons of milk a day and practically so since the 10th of February.

In a few weeks we will have 3 more cows to calve, and later, 4 more. In May, for the latest, we will certainly have from 40 to 60 gallons a day. We have 12 cows all under eight years old. Next year, we expect to have 2 more if we have no accident.

Anyway, the one who reported that we did not give an adequate supply of milk to the children should know that when cows are near calving it is not good to milk them nor is the milk of first quality; also that last year during a very dry year, the pasture was not abundant nor very green in September and October; our provision of green feed was not therefore very abundant, only about 15 tons and also hay. It is not enough to make the cows give milk all through the hard season.

The reporter said we had only 8 cows, we have 12 at present, but I am glad that this remark was made! 9 cows, because we have only 8 stands for cows in the stable. In fact, we are obliged to put 4 cows and calves along with the horses. Our stable is rather small but it was built at our own expense. Now 2 Holstein cows excepted, which were given by the authority of Mr. Graham, the Indian Commissioner, we have received no help from the Indian Department.

Would it not then be a very kind deed of the Department to give us any fund to enlarge the stable or even build a new one, and buy for us 4 or 5 more good milch cows as it has been done for other schools which I envy very much?
I hope that these remarks will make you understand what we are doing for the welfare of our children and also give you good suggestions to help us in a larger measure for our stable and stock.

I am, dear Sir,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Principal.
Ottawa, March 19, 1930.

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of
Mary Lightning, Pupil No. 616,
of the Ermineskin Indian Residential School at Hattima,
who died at Hattima (place) on 28th April 1937.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

of the Ermineskin Indian Residential School at Hinton,

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina,

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit the following:

At your recent visit to our School you may have noticed the large attendance we had, and it is steadily increasing. We have, actually, an enrolment of 113 pupils.

I would like to point out to you the fact that we have but eight (8) milch cows; you will readily understand that the supply of milk is inadequate to the needs, and that, consequently, an increase in the stock would be of prime importance.

Now, will you kindly lay before the Department the request that we be supplied with four (4) pure-bred Holstein cows. We feel convinced that the only response which can be given to it is a favorable one, since the Department values your opinions so highly.

Relying upon your efficiency as a powerful advocate in our cause, and hoping that the Department will accede to our request, I remain,

Yours very gratefully,

Rev. P. P. Moulin, O.M.I.

They have 12 cows at the school. This, in my opinion, is not a sufficient number for an institution that has 145 pupils, besides staff, and as you will realize, there are always times when some of the cows are not giving milk. The quantity of milk they are receiving at the present time is very small, but they had a number of cows that would freshen shortly. They only have stable accommodation for 12 cows, and I do not suppose the Sisters feel that they are in a position to buy any additional cows or build an addition to the barn. I noticed also that their pig pen is very small, and does not provide sufficient room for the pigs that they wish to raise, but I was told that they could not finance the erection of a better pig sty at the present time.
The children at the Ermineskin's School are apparently well cared for, but it seems to me they are not getting the proper food, when seven or eight cows are supposed to supply milk for 140 people. The Department should insist on the proper amount of milk being supplied to the pupils at our Indian schools.

I think that in many cases we are giving medical attention for illness, when the illness could well be avoided. I am sure Dr. Stone will agree with me that when Indian children are not properly fed they are very susceptible to tuberculosis and other complaints.
Ottawa, February 25, 1930.

Sir:

The attention of the Department has been drawn to the inadequacy of the milk supply furnished for the daily use of the pupils of the Ermineskin's Indian Residential School. As you are aware, the Department expects that these institutions will supply milk to the children in sufficient quantities, as it is considered one of the most important items of the children's diet. We are informed that the school has at present only 7 or 8 cows, from which the entire milk supply is obtained for the daily use of the pupils and staff.

You should take up this matter with the Principal and inform him it is expected he will arrange, if there are not other cows in the herd that will soon freshen, for the purchase of a further number of milk cows sufficient to provide an ample supply of milk for the pupils' daily requirements. A request has been made for an increased milking as from April 1st, next, but, unless the Department is assured that an adequate supply of milk will be available, favourable consideration could not be given this request. After fully discussing the matter of a good milk supply with the Principal, you should inform the Department of the action he intends taking to increase the number of milk cows and in furnishing an adequate daily milk supply for the pupils' requirements.

Your obedient servant,

Emineskin Residential School,
Hobbema, Alta., March 7, 1930.

To the Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs.

Dear Sir,

The Indian Agent Mr. Askey gave me knowledge yesterday of a very surprising letter received recently from the Indian Department.

It has been reported that we did not give an adequate supply of milk to the pupils of the School. When the Inspector Christianson from Regina office was visiting our School at the end of January, he asked how many cows we were milking and our man said: Two.

It was true but the Inspector did not put any other question, nor made inquiry; it would surprise me very much that a man of his standing would have reported thus only after that one question.

The fact was we had one cow that was fresh and the other was giving yet milk. Two more could have been milked but scarcity of green feed would have made it hard for them. About a week or ten days after his passage, we had 5 cows that calved and one recently. We have now an average of 20 to 24 gallons of milk a day and practically so since the 10th of February.

In a few weeks we will have 3 more cows to calve, and later, 4 more. In May, for the latest, we will certainly have from 40 to 60 gallons a day. We have 12 cows all under eight years old. Next year, we expect to have 2 more if we have no accident.

Anyway, the one who reported that we did not give an adequate supply of milk to the children should know that when cows are near calving it is not good to milk them nor is the milk of first quality. Also that last year within a short year, the pasture was not abundant nor very green in September and October; our provision of green feed was not therefore very abundant, only about 15 tons and also hay.

Hay is not enough to make the cows give milk all through the hard season.

The reporter said we had only 8 cows. We have 12 at present but I am glad that this remark was made: 8 cows, because we have only 6 stands for cows in the stable. In fact, we are obliged to put 4 cows and calves along with the horses. Our stable is rather small but it was built at our own expense. Now, 2 Holstein cows excepted, which were given by the authority of Mr. Graham, the Indian Commissioner, we have received no help from the Indian Department.

Would it not then be a very kind deed of the Department to give us any fund to enlarge the stable or even build a new one, and buy for us 4 or 5 more good milk cows as it has been done for other schools which I envy very much?
I hope that these remarks will make you understand what we are doing for the welfare of our children and also give you good suggestions to help us in a larger measure for our stable and stock.

I am, dear Sir,

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

Yesterday, I had a letter from the Acting Indian Agent stating that the Indian Department could not afford to give us a sulky plow, but that it was to the school to provide for this equipment.

I regard to say that at the present time we are too much in debt as you know to make this purchase. In the past 1912-1914 we remodeled our school in order to have the increase per capita; in 1922 we enlarged the school and went in debt up to $17,000; in 1929, we had another addition and repairs made to our own expenses, costing over $8,000.

Other schools had not to go to these expenses, but entirely rebuilt by the Indian Department, they are given stock and implements for their farming commodities. We will then wait to the day when the Indian Department will rebuild our school and give us the means of teaching far work to our pupils.

ERMINESKIN INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

HOBBEMA, ALTA. September 28, 1943.

Dear Sir,

I have been appointed Bursar at the Ermineskin Indian Residential school, Hobbema, with the instruction of establishing a farm in connection with the school and teach the boys a few things about the machinery and the methods of farming in the West, which will be the natural mode of making a living for them. There is an embryo of a farm so far, with practically no machines, and I have decided to buy a tractor, latter on the other machines will follow, but I find that it is almost impossible to get anything in this line unless you have a permit from the Board of Priorities. Most Agents have it but Hobbema is not in this favored category, and it is why I am asking to get it for me. I do not know yet what make of tractor I will buy, I will decide as soon as I have the permit. I suppose it is too early yet to know if there is any tractors discarded by the army, available for our kind of work.

Thanking you most sincerely, I remain respectfully Yours,

E. Runux, O.M.F.

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of
Marie Lightning, Pupil No. 616,
of the Ermineskin Indian Residential School at Attawapiskat,
who died at Attawapiskat (place) on 28th July 1937.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of

Marie Lightning, Pupil No. 614,

of the Commission Indian Residential School at Hinton,

who died at Hinton (place) on 28th April 1937.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

I herewith submit the Quarterly Return of
the Holy Angels Indian Residential School for the Quarter
ended June 30. The following remarks complete it:

1. The Primary Classroom was open 45.5 days during the quarter;
   the Intermediate Classroom ... 44.5 days;
   the Senior Classroom .......... 44 days.

2. The classrooms re-opened after Easter on the 8th of April.

3. From the 11th to the 28th of April, the three classrooms
   were closed by order of the District Nurse on account of an
   epidemic of flu. Many day scholars, all the pupils resident
   at the school and several members of the staff fell within
   the first four days, but all were able to resume their tasks
   after two weeks.

4. In June, four days were allowed for the cutting of potato
   seed and the planting.

Yours respectfully,

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. 9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. Extract from Report of Inspector H.M. Conroy, on the Boarding Schools in Treaty No. 8 and Mackenzie District, Dated December 18, 1911. Original on File 160370-15E

CHIPEWYAN

The Boarding school at Chipewyan, under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Mission, is one main building with two wings. Its length fronting on the lake, is 105 feet. The school is well situated on high ground, protected on three sides by rising ground and timber and is only exposed to a south wind from the lake.

The foundations are of stone, 18 inches thick. The walls are logs, sheeted both outside and inside with planks. Galleries opening from the ground and second floors run the entire frontage of the building.

The building is economically planned, the rooms are all exceptionally well lighted, and the ventilation is very fair.

There are four dormitories, two for boys and two for girls. Their measurements are 37 x 32 x 8; 32 x 66 x 8; 31 x 22 x 8 and 37 x 32 x 8. These give accommodation according to Departmental regulation, for 51 pupils. The class rooms are two in number; one 32 x 23 x 76, accommodating with regard to floor space 75 pupils, and cubic space 32 pupils. The other is 37 x 20 x 76, accommodating (floor space) 46 pupils and (cubic space) 22 pupils. The total accommodation is for 54 pupils. The average attendance is about 45. There is no hospital, but a special room is kept for cases of sickness. There are two fire escapes from...
Chipewyan con.

the dormitories.

Two hot air furnaces give every satisfaction, stoves are also placed in the larger dormitories and class rooms.

The water supply is obtained from a force pump from the lake to the kitchen, where the reservoirs are placed. An independent pump is kept ready in case of fire. There is also a well in the rear of the building.

The class work follows pretty closely the regulations of the Department. The girls are taught sewing and cooking, and the boys are taught elementary carpentry and farming. The boys help in the general work around the Mission. The girls take turns in the kitchen and are given enough practical experience to stand them in good stead when they leave school.

The Mission has drained a little lake in the rear to provide a garden. There they raise enough vegetables for use in the school, and about 800 bushels of potatoes.

The Mission owns eight cows, a bull, and four heifers.

I would recommend that the Department send in two blackboards, a dozen desks, some wall maps of the Dominion and the north country, and a globe.

Dear Sir,

Enclosed you will find petition of the Chipewen Convent. As per the petition I have visited the Institution at St. Albert and I find that the installation will be about $600. This is exclusive of the cost of drilling the well, and the usual cost is so much per foot, I am not aware of the amount. The circumstances are these: Chipewen is situated on the mouth of Lake Athabasca, and the Athabasca River flows into the mouth of the Lake down in the Rocky River, which empties into the Slave at the Junction of the Peace and the Slave. The Athabasca River is very muddy at all times of the year except late in the fall and early in the spring. The Lake is extremely muddy by reason of its shallow waters (maximum depth in normal water 8 to 10 ft.) for a distance of about 25 miles towards Fond du Lac. It becomes, therefore, impossible for any of the institutions at Chipewen to get clear water during the greater part of the year. In the main, and the only water available is the Lake water. This has proven to be a source of danger to the children in attendance, and whilst visiting the northern
district the Sisters asked me to request the Government assistance.

The well which would be dug for the Sisters could be used by a large portion of the population of Chipewyan, it being only a small trading post. Whilst this may not be considered public works, I can vouch for the fact that the request made by the Sisters is a very reasonable one indeed.

I travelled the Athabasca, the Rockey and Slave Rivers for a distance of 700 miles and I always welcomed a brook from which I could get clear water to drink. Even when the water is settled in pails and barrels, it is at best riley. From a sanitary point of view it seems that the Government ought to do something for that Institution, which is established for the public welfare, which at best is living in seclusion for the sake of Christianity and education of children.

I trust you will give this request a favourable consideration.

Yours sincerely,

(SGD) H.A. Mackie.

Nov. 20th, 1915.

In regard to the proposal from Mr. A. Mackie that the Department should assist the Catholic mission in their efforts to provide a supply of well water for the institution at Chipewyan I have to report that although it would be a very desirable thing to have a supply of well water at this institution yet the natural obstacles are of such a serious character that in my opinion the cost of construction and installation would be prohibitive.

The country in the neighbourhood of the School is very rocky, and it is a very questionable matter as to whether it is at all possible to drill down more than 10 or 15 feet between the rock ridges without striking rock.

A good well has been in use at the Chipewyan settlement for several years, and is situated at the Hudson's Bay Co. post, but it is probably about 1000 yds distant from the mission. This well is not the sole source of the drinking water supply, for during a great part of the time, the ordinary lake water is used by the community. It rarely occurs that Athabasca Lake recedes to such a low level as was in evidence this summer at the time when Mr. Mackie
was visiting the settlement. When the lake is at its ordinary level the water is easily accessible and not unduly impregnated with mud or silt, so that it is quite fit for drinking purposes.

If the mission would make some preliminary effort in the direction of locating a supply of well water, I would have no hesitation in recommending that assistance be given toward the expense of boring or drilling, and cribbing work, but until an indication of water can be obtained it would in my opinion constitute a departure from the usual policy of the Department to become liable for an expenditure which cannot be estimated or controlled, and for which there would be no guarantee of proportionate results.

Madam,

Mr. Mackie, M.P., called at the Department a few days ago in reference to the water supply for the Holy Angels Boarding School, Fort Chipewyan.

This matter has been before the Department for sometime, but, owing to the uncertainty of securing a sufficient supply of well water for the institution, on account of natural obstacles, the excessive cost of drilling through the rocks and the shortage of funds owing to the war, nothing so far has been done to relieve the situation. The Department would, therefore, be pleased if you would request the mission authorities to have a careful examination.

Mr. Scott.

The Holy Angels boarding school at Chippewayan, on Athabasca lake, have had extreme difficulty in providing an adequate water supply for their institution, the site and vicinity being rocky, in which it is difficult and costly to drill, with uncertain water possibilities from that source. The Athabasca lake has also been an uncertain source, owing to the receding of the water of this during the season of low water, when the accumulation of silt in the margin of the lake, (largely vegetable matter,) renders this water unfit for use.

The school authorities have, after many efforts, succeeded in finding the solution, they having dug a well on the bank of the lake, which is reported to contain an abundant supply of pure water, which is filtered from the lake through the intervening sand.

The estimate of the school for completing the work is placed at $1,500.00. There is no data supplied, however, showing how this cost is arrived at or the height to which the water is to be elevated, and, in the absence of this, an approximate estimate has been made, which would appear to be reasonable, viz.: -

MEMORANDUM:

With reference to the waterworks for the Holy Angels Boarding School at Chipewyan, I beg to report as follows.

Some system of waterworks is an absolute necessity. They have been hauling water from the lake, which in low water is quite a distance from them. This is not satisfactory, and would be disastrous in case of fire.

The Mission has found good water some 300 feet from the School; and if this is so, I think that either a wind mill or a gasoline engine should be installed. Two tanks will be needed, 750 gals. each, one for the general needs of the school, and one for fire protection. They can be installed for about $500. If the Mission furnishes the labor. Of course they will have to be placed high enough to give gravitation, and in some place where they will not freeze.

If a plant can be installed for $1500, it will be a very reasonable price, provided that for this price the Mission is able to secure something that will be satisfactory. As the Mission seem to think that they can provide and install the plant for this price, and as it is a very reasonable figure, I would recommend that it be allowed. Some system is absolutely necessary.

Honorable Sir,

As I wrote in my last report, our mission has been threatened with destruction. On the fifth of April during dinner time, our sister Mary, coming back from her visit to the sick, saw fire and thick smoke rising through the roof of the right wing near the chimney.

The church bell called for help and soon all the people in Chipewyan was at the scene. The fight against the terrible flames lasted nearly two hours before complete victory could be won. The firemen extinguishers have proved to be very efficacious, but we had not enough of them. Water was carried in tons with two sleighs from the lake (about 15 mile distance).

We expressed heartfelt thanks to the devoted workers who displayed heroic efforts in the circumstance.

The fire began near the chimney. The roof was bored in several places; the interior of the roof is completely burnt with all that was in the attic. Damage has been caused also by throwing the furniture through the window-panes from the gallery. Our school desks (old and new) tall tables were all broken; now roughly repaired, they have a poor appearance. It is an opportunity to try and have modern desks—but oh... we cannot afford to make that expense.
Should not the Department make us a gratification which would be in some time a present for our golden jubilee that we will celebrate in the spring 1847? For thirty years we have raised and taught the children of this country at our expense, and treated the sick in the same way.

May I hope to begin my twenty-fifth year teaching in Chipewayan with favorable duties?

Expecting a favorable answer,

I beg to remain,

Honourably Sir,

Yours obediently,

M. Z. Dufault.

DESCRIPTION OF HINGE

Read This Carefully---It is Important

NO Chain is stronger than its weakest link. Also the life of a school desk cannot be greater than the life of the hinge. In the development of the New Globe Automatic our energy was directed toward the elimination of faults in the Hinge.

OUR SUCCESS IS COMPLETE

We sincerely believe that the Hinge in the New Automatic is the strongest Automatic Seat Hinge ever invented and comes nearer to being noiseless than any other now on the market.

Absolute noiselessness can only be secured by the use of rubber or leather buffers, or springs and when such parts are used it is only a question of time till they become worn or dislodged and must then be replaced or the desk is too noisy for further use.

Those who have had experience in getting repairs for school desks know how difficult and unsatisfactory it is, and, therefore, the desk that will wear the longest without needing repairs is the most valuable one to the school.

There are fewer parts in the Hinge of the New Globe than are found in any other School Desk Hinge on the market. This alone reduces the possibility of its getting out of order.

It does not depend on bumpers or rubber, leather or other material, nor on springs of any kind for its noiseless action.

The steel balls used in the Hinge are one-half inch in diameter, being twice as large as those used by any other manufacturer, thus giving greater wear resisting qualities.

The balls in the Hinge of the New Globe ARE NOT held in position by means of springs, because when such is the case the spring will in time lose its tension allowing the balls to get out of their proper position, or draw out entirely.

In the Hinge of the New Globe the steel balls absorb all friction, there being no wearing contact of iron against iron. In every other so-called Ball Bearing Desk there is a wearing contact of iron against iron.

The accompanying diagram, Fig. 1, will give you a clear accurate understanding of the great simplicity of the Hinge, and you will note that "A" is the Seat Arm; "B" shows a portion of the Desk Top or Casting. When the seat is raised the Ball "P" fits into the socket "Q." The Shoulder "R" on "A" moves in Groove "S" on "B" when the seat is raised or lowered. Ball "O" rests in the Seat "R" and acts as a stop for the seating "B" at "S" between "J" and "K." The Casting grows gradually thicker as it nears the point "K" so that the Ball rolls less easily as it reaches the end of its course. This brings the seat to a gradual stop without jar or noise. When the seat is lowered the ball rolls towards "J" where the casting is also thicker. The seat comes to a gradual stop in the same way and for the same reason as when it is raised.

The office of the Bolt "T" and the Cap "Q" is merely to hold the parts together. The bolt passes through the Seat Arm and the Slot "G" cuts through Casting "B" and "H." The notch "E" Casting "I" is placed over the Lug "C" on "B" to prevent "D"s" turning with the Seat Arm.

The Lugs "L," "M," and "N" prevent the Seat from raising or lowering beyond the proper position and also carry a part of the weight of the pupil, thus relieving the working parts of some of the strain.

Permettez-moi de Vous appeler un besoin de Notre Boarding school ou Couvent des Saintes Anges, fort Chipewyan. Boarding School de 82 enfants actuellement dont presque la moitié des orphelins à notre charge. C'est au sujet de l'eau.

Sir:

Permit me to inform you of the great need of our boarding school of the Convent of the Holy Angels, Fort Chipewyan. This boarding school has at present eighty-two (82) children, of which about one-half are orphans in our charge. It is about the water.

We get our supply of water from the Athabasca Lake. This water is of a very poor quality especially in the spring and fall. To obviate this inconvenience, instead of affairs we would like to dig a well on the edge of the lake. It is in front of our school and about three hundred (300') feet from the building. About twenty (20') feet deep there is excellent water. We have seen the facts before and what we would need about twenty (20) barrels of Portland Cement; One (1) Anti-Freeze Pump and a small Motor of three and one-half (3½) H.P., and about fifty (50') feet of pipe. The full installation should not cost over five hundred ($500.00) dollars.

This is what I take the liberty of asking you to give us for the sanitary benefit of our children. However, small may be the expenditure we are unable to meet such expenses.

Hoping that you will be kind enough to consider our demand, I remain with sincere thanks

Yours, etc.,

C. Joussard, O.M.I.,
Co-Ajutor

INSPECTOR'S OFFICE
FB CALGARY, ALTA, February 27th, 1935.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to report on an inspection of the Holy Angels Indian Residential School at Fort Chipewyan, which is run under the management of the Roman Catholic Church; and as far as I know they personally own the building and equipment at this institution. The School is situated just at the South end of the village, bordering on the river. This institution was built something like 70 years ago, according to information I received. The original building was of logs but I presume it has been sheeted inside and out several times, and although it is very old it is still in a good state of repair. The ceilings, of course, are not up to standard heights, and the halls are narrow, but the building has a lot of windows, and when the thermometer gets down between 60° and 70° below zero in the winter time, it is not very difficult to get an abundance of fresh air into the building. I went over the school and looked over the equipment, and everything was in good order. The children had good beds to sleep in; home-made, but

Doctor Harold W. McGill,

Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
all has good feather ticks as mattresses and lots of bedding. You will realize that where there is an abundance of geese and ducks it is not difficult to get lots of feathers for ticks.

There are two classrooms in the building. One classroom was supplied with the regular school seats, old type, but the other one had home-made tables and benches.

I also looked over the fire-hazard at the school, and I am sure we all realize that in an old frame building of that nature there is always danger of fire. However I think all precautions are being taken that possibly can be to eliminate risk. There is, of course a set of stairs inside the building. Then there are two sets of stairs down to the ground on the outside of the building, one at each end. There are also several fire extinguishers in the building; but in case of fire the main thing would be to get the children all out of the school and not stop to use fire extinguishers. I might mention that the building is not very high and if there was a fire, especially in the winter time, it would not hurt the children to jump out through the windows. I also noticed that axes were kept handy in case of the necessity of breaking windows or doors. Two sisters sleep in each dormitory.

The building is heated by two hot-air furnaces situated on the main floor. There is no modern convenience in this institution of any kind and water is hauled by team from the lake and dumped into the cistern. The school
authorities were just completing the erection of an ice house and refrigeration plant to enable them to keep their food supplies during the summer months, which I am sure is quite a problem in an out-of-the-way place like Fort Chipewyan.

There is a new hip-roof barn at the school which houses the cattle and horses. There are also several storehouses and outbuildings and a separate building for all the male members of the staff. As the buildings do not belong to the Department I presume this is sufficient report in connection with the same.

LIVE STOCK:

The school keeps a few head of cattle under great difficulties. Last fall they had to get rid of several animals on account of the scarcity of feed. The Principal informed me that they were hauling hay 50 miles. They had 9 cows, 4 horses and about 100 chickens.

A small farm is operated by the school but the crop is cut for feed. Last fall they harvested 750 sacks of potatoes and an abundance of other garden truck.

It might be interesting to the Department to know that in 1892 some wheat raised by the school authorities there received 1st prize at the World's Fair in Chicago. They have no trouble in raising gardens up in that part of the country if they can find the soil. Around Fort Chipewyan this is
difficult as the land around there is principally composed of rock.

At the time of my visit there were 79 children in residence at the school: 39 Treaty and 40 non-Treaty. As we approached the school Doctor Lewis made the following remarks: "Mr. Christianson, I know you have seen Indian children in residential schools all over the country, but I am sure you have never seen a healthier lot than we have in this institution;" and after I had seen them I quite agreed with the doctor's statement: There was no illness of any kind in the school, nor did I notice a sickly looking child amongst them; and they are evidently well fed and cared for in every way. In conversation with the Sister Superior I learned that the children always receive a meal of fish per day. This winter they have been able to get an abundance of cariboo meat and in every way the children more or less live as in their natural environment, receiving pretty much the same food as they do in their own homes, but a little better. I was in the dining room when the children were eating and they seemed to be getting all the food they required, which is born out by the appearance of the children. I saw the children at one time or another practically every day, as I often passed the school, and called in there, &c., and they were all well clad.

The training carried on there is more
or less along the requirements of the North:
The girls learn to make moccasins, to do
silk work on leather, to knit and make their
own clothes, &c. They are also taught cook-
ing and learn how to make bread and bannock,
and in every way they are taught things that
will be useful to them when they leave the
school. The main thing is not to keep any of
the children in school too long, as the boys
have no avocation to go to when they are dis-
charged other than that of their fathers and
forefathers, viz., to make a living off the
land by hunting, trapping and fishing.

The classroom work at the school
seemed to be very satisfactory, and I found
that some of the children had gone as high
as Grade VI. Both teachers were quite effici-
ent in their work; and I was surprised to
meet Sister Robinette, who was at one time
the senior girls' teacher at Lebret, and an
excellent teacher, having had years of ex-
perience.

The staff of the school consists of
the following: 12 Sisters of Charity belong-
ing to the order of Grey Nuns of Montreal;
Five priests at the mission and three brothers,
as well as 5 other male employees. During the
last 3 or 4 years, or since Doctor Lewis came
to Fort Chipewyan, there have been many changes
in the personnel of the school. The Rev. Sis-
ter McQuillan is the Superior. She is an Irish
Sister and Doctor Lewis informed me that she
was very efficient. Rev. Father Caudier is
Principal of the school, and he has occupied this position for approximately two years. I considered him a very capable Principal and the Agent informed me that he was of the same opinion. Father Caudier left for the East while I was at Fort Chipewyan, and he will probably call on the Department when he is in Ottawa.

During my stay up there the School put on a concert in my honour and invited most of the settlers from the village to it, and it was enjoyed by all present. I must say they made a very creditable showing.

In conclusion I would say that in my opinion Holly Angels School is carrying on splendid work in spite of great handicaps.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.
