Sir:

I have been directed to acknowledge receipt of your 410-11A, R.C. of the 27th ultimo, reporting on your inspection of the Holy Angels Indian Residential School at Fort Chipewyan.

In reply I have to say the Department is pleased to note that the children at this school are in a very healthy condition, that they are well fed and cared for in every way.

The buildings at this school are the property of the Roman Catholic Church. I note that they are in a good state of repair and that the equipment was in good order. No doubt, there is a certain fire hazard in buildings of the type at this school. I have noted your opinion that all precautions are being taken by the staff to eliminate risk of fire.

It is noted, further, that the classroom work appeared to you to be very satisfactory, that there is an efficient and experienced staff, and that this school is doing splendid work.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Sir,

Referring to our conversation re Holy Angels' School at Fort Chipewyan, I humbly wish to draw your attention on the urgent need of rebuilding this school, a need which you had the opportunity of acknowledging during your visit last year. Unfortunately we are actually compelled to suspend the work through lack of funds to purchase the necessary material. We have in view a fire-proof building. Before proceeding any further we would like to be sure that the Department is willing to cooperate as soon as circumstances permit.

As stated previously in our conversation, a promise by the Government of a grant of $30,000 in next year's estimates would be quite satisfactory. We can guarantee the balance required for the rebuilding of the school.

With the hope that our request will meet a favourable reply,

I remain

Dear Mr Phelan,

I wish to thank you for your letter of the 17th instant - file 141-2-5 - in connection with vouchers for the night watchman at the I.R. Schools located in the Mackenzie Diocese. Should it happen that in the future the vouchers would have not reached your office, I would gladly furnish you with any assistance you may require and see to it that our schools do not delay in sending same.

When checking lately all payments received from the Department for night watchman at the I.R. School of Fort-Providence, N.W.T., I found that up to the present time, no payment has been received through our Bank for the abovesaid night watchman since the beginning of the present year, that is last October 1937. So, I was wondering whether you have received no reports for that school, or whether the cheques have been mailed directly to the Principal at Fort-Providence. Your answer regarding this matter will be greatly appreciated.

As regards to the payment for night watchman at the Holy Angels' school of Fort-Chipewyan, I found cheques 648982-64205-69950-, being respectively for the months of October, December & January, February. According to our records, I do not find any payment made for the month of November, unless this payment has been made directly to the school. Will you please let me know whether this month has been paid or not.

Payments for the other I.R. Schools, viz., Resolution and Aklavik have been all received.

Thanking you for past favors,
I am,
Yours respectfully,

Father J. Serrurrot, O.M.I.,

Along with all our other demands upon our finances comes the water supply in Fort Chipewyan. The water is very low and hence it requires a long pipe to reach the water fit for drinking. Right Reverend Sir:

I am directed to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 12th instant requesting pipe for the Holy Angels (Fort Chipewyan) Indian Residential School.

All purchases are now made by our Purchasing Agent and it is, therefore, necessary for us to have specific information regarding what is required. I would, therefore, appreciate if you would let me have full particulars regarding the 2000 feet of pipe which will be required at the Holy Angels school. You should state whether you require tile or iron pipe, also its diameter and the length of each section of the pipe. As soon as this information is obtained I will arrange to have our purchasing agent secure it. I note from your letter that you estimate the cost at $400.00.

Extract from letter dated June 10, 1938, file 451-1, from Dr. P. W. Head, Medical Superintendent, addressed to Dr. H. N. McGill:

Your letter of the above date to hand and carefully studied.

The situation in this Agency regarding the control of Tuberculosis is very poor.

The only residential school in this Agency is at Fort Chipewyan and it also takes in day school pupils of half-breed and white families.

The school is an old antiquated building with no facilities for carrying out segregation of tubercular pupils and it has been my custom to discharge any active cases that may arise. Any cases that I consider not active but need extra attention I attempt to put on hospital routine with special food.

I do not think a great deal can be done towards the control of Tuberculosis until we have a more modern residential school and a hospital located at this point.

(Sgd.) P. W. Head, M.D.
Medical Superintendent.
